Jordan Measure

Let III be an interval of the real line. The length of III given by ∣I∣|I|∣I∣ can be recovered by the limiting formula
∣I∣=lim⁡N→∞1N#(I∩1NZ)|I| = \lim_{N \to \infty} \frac{1}{N} \#(I \cap \frac{1}{N} Z)∣I∣=N→∞lim​N1​#(I∩N1​Z)
where: 1NZ:={nN:n∈Z}\frac{1}{N} Z := \{\frac{n}{N}: n \in Z\}N1​Z:={Nn​:n∈Z}, ZZZ is the set of integers and #(A)\#(A)#(A) denotes the cardinality of the finite set AAA.

Prove this statement.

Below is a standard proof that for a (bounded) interval I⊂RI \subset \mathbb{R}I⊂R, its length ∣I∣\lvert I\rvert∣I∣ can be recovered by counting how many points of the form nN\tfrac{n}{N}Nn​ (with n∈Zn \in \mathbb{Z}n∈Z) lie in III and then dividing by NNN. Indeed, one often writes:

∣I∣  =  lim⁡N→∞1N #(I∩1NZ),\lvert I\rvert \;=\; \lim_{N \to \infty} \frac{1}{N}\,\#\bigl(I \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}\bigr),∣I∣=N→∞lim​N1​#(I∩N1​Z),

which is a well-known way to recover the length (Lebesgue measure) of III. Below is a step-by-step proof for the case of a closed and bounded interval I=[a,b]I = [a,b]I=[a,b]. One can adapt the reasoning to open, half-open, or other intervals with minor modifications.

  1. Setup and notation

• Let I=[a,b]I = [a,b]I=[a,b] be a (closed) bounded interval in R\mathbb{R}R.
• For each positive integer NNN, define
AN  =  I∩1NZ  =  {nN:n∈Z,  nN∈[a,b]}.A_N \;=\; I \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z} \;=\; \bigl\{ \tfrac{n}{N} : n\in \mathbb{Z}, \;\tfrac{n}{N}\in [a,b] \bigr\}.AN​=I∩N1​Z={Nn​:n∈Z,Nn​∈[a,b]}.
• Let #AN\#A_N#AN​ denote the number of elements in ANA_NAN​. Since nN∈[a,b]\tfrac{n}{N}\in [a,b]Nn​∈[a,b] forces nnn to be in a finite range, #AN\#A_N#AN​ is a finite integer.

We want to show
∣I∣  =  b−a  =  lim⁡N→∞1N #(AN).\lvert I\rvert \;=\; b-a \;=\; \lim_{N\to \infty} \frac{1}{N}\,\#(A_N).∣I∣=b−a=N→∞lim​N1​#(AN​).

  1. Counting the number of multiples in the interval

Observe that
AN  =  {nN:n∈Z,  a ≤ nN ≤ b}.A_N \;=\; \left\{ \tfrac{n}{N} : n \in \mathbb{Z}, \; a \,\le\, \tfrac{n}{N} \,\le\, b \right\}.AN​={Nn​:n∈Z,a≤Nn​≤b}.
This means
a  ≤  nN  ≤  b⟺aN  ≤  n  ≤  bN.a \;\le\; \tfrac{n}{N} \;\le\; b \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad aN \;\le\; n \;\le\; bN.a≤Nn​≤b⟺aN≤n≤bN.
Hence the integers nnn that belong to ANA_NAN​ must satisfy
n  ∈  {⌈aN⌉,  ⌈aN⌉+1,…,⌊bN⌋−1,  ⌊bN⌋}.n \;\in\; \bigl\{ \lceil aN \rceil, \; \lceil aN \rceil + 1, \ldots, \lfloor bN \rfloor-1,\; \lfloor bN \rfloor \bigr\}.n∈{⌈aN⌉,⌈aN⌉+1,…,⌊bN⌋−1,⌊bN⌋}.
Therefore,
#AN  =  ⌊bN⌋  −  ⌈aN⌉  +  1.\#A_N \;=\; \lfloor bN \rfloor \;-\; \lceil aN \rceil \;+\; 1.#AN​=⌊bN⌋−⌈aN⌉+1.
(The “+1+1+1” accounts for including both endpoints in the count of integers.)

  1. Bounding #AN\#A_N#AN​ from above and below

We know that for any real number xxx,
x−1<⌊x⌋  ≤  x,x≤⌈x⌉<x+1.x-1 < \lfloor x \rfloor \;\le\; x, \quad x \le \lceil x \rceil < x + 1.x−1<⌊x⌋≤x,x≤⌈x⌉<x+1.
Applying these to ⌊bN⌋\lfloor bN\rfloor⌊bN⌋ and ⌈aN⌉\lceil aN\rceil⌈aN⌉:

  1. ⌊bN⌋  ≥  bN−1.\lfloor bN \rfloor \;\ge\; bN - 1.⌊bN⌋≥bN−1.
  2. ⌈aN⌉  ≤  aN+1.\lceil aN \rceil \;\le\; aN + 1.⌈aN⌉≤aN+1.

Thus
#AN  =  ⌊bN⌋−⌈aN⌉+1  ≥  (bN−1)−(aN+1)+1  =  (b−a) N  −  1.\#A_N \;=\; \lfloor bN \rfloor - \lceil aN \rceil + 1 \;\ge\; \bigl(bN - 1\bigr) - \bigl(aN + 1\bigr) + 1 \;=\; (b-a)\,N \;-\; 1.#AN​=⌊bN⌋−⌈aN⌉+1≥(bN−1)−(aN+1)+1=(b−a)N−1.
Similarly,
#AN  =  ⌊bN⌋−⌈aN⌉+1  ≤  ⌊bN⌋−(aN)+1  ≤  (bN)−(aN)+1  =  (b−a) N+1.\#A_N \;=\; \lfloor bN \rfloor - \lceil aN \rceil + 1 \;\le\; \lfloor bN\rfloor - \bigl(aN\bigr) + 1 \;\le\; (bN) - (aN) + 1 \;=\; (b-a)\,N + 1.#AN​=⌊bN⌋−⌈aN⌉+1≤⌊bN⌋−(aN)+1≤(bN)−(aN)+1=(b−a)N+1.
Hence
(b−a) N−1  ≤  #AN  ≤  (b−a) N+1.(b-a)\,N - 1 \;\le\; \#A_N \;\le\; (b-a)\,N + 1.(b−a)N−1≤#AN​≤(b−a)N+1.

  1. Dividing by NNN and taking the limit

Divide the above chain of inequalities by N>0N>0N>0:

(b−a)  −  1N    ≤    #ANN    ≤    (b−a)  +  1N.(b-a) \;-\; \frac{1}{N} \;\;\le\;\; \frac{\#A_N}{N} \;\;\le\;\; (b-a) \;+\; \frac{1}{N}.(b−a)−N1​≤N#AN​​≤(b−a)+N1​.
As N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞, both of the bounds
(b−a)  −  1Nand(b−a)  +  1N(b-a)\;-\;\frac{1}{N} \quad\text{and}\quad (b-a)\;+\;\frac{1}{N}(b−a)−N1​and(b−a)+N1​
converge to (b−a)(b-a)(b−a). By the squeeze theorem, we conclude
lim⁡N→∞#(AN)N  =  b−a  =  ∣I∣.\lim_{N\to\infty} \frac{\#(A_N)}{N} \;=\; b-a \;=\; \lvert I\rvert.N→∞lim​N#(AN​)​=b−a=∣I∣.

In other words,
∣I∣  =  lim⁡N→∞1N  #(I ∩ 1NZ).\lvert I\rvert \;=\; \lim_{N\to \infty} \frac{1}{N}\;\#\bigl(I \,\cap\, \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}\bigr).∣I∣=N→∞lim​N1​#(I∩N1​Z).

  1. Remarks on variants of the statement

• If one uses the union I∪1NZI \cup \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}I∪N1​Z, this set is typically infinite, so #(I∪1NZ)=∞\#\bigl(I \cup \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}\bigr) = \infty#(I∪N1​Z)=∞. The usual statement is indeed about the intersection I∩1NZI \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}I∩N1​Z.
• If III is not bounded or not closed, one can refine the above argument by approximating III by bounded closed intervals or handling endpoints carefully. The limit argument remains essentially the same and the length is still recovered.
• This formula is a discrete analog of the idea behind Riemann integration: counting how many equally-spaced points fall into III is akin to a Riemann sum for the indicator function of III.

Thus the key takeaway is:

For a bounded interval I=[a,b],lim⁡N→∞1N #(I∩1NZ)  =  b−a  =  ∣I∣.\boxed{ \text{For a bounded interval }I = [a,b],\quad \lim_{N\to \infty} \dfrac{1}{N}\,\#\Bigl(I \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}\Bigr) \;=\; b - a \;=\; \lvert I\rvert. }For a bounded interval I=[a,b],N→∞lim​N1​#(I∩N1​Z)=b−a=∣I∣.​

I am having trouble on the intuition of this result. We seem to be equating the cardinality of a set with the length of an interval which does not seem to make sense. By measuring the cardinality are we measuring the number of equal length sub intervals in III? Provide an intuitive explanation.

Here is one intuitive way to think about the identity
∣I∣  =  lim⁡N→∞1N #(I∩1NZ).|I| \;=\; \lim_{N\to\infty} \frac{1}{N}\,\#\Bigl(I \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}\Bigr).∣I∣=N→∞lim​N1​#(I∩N1​Z).

  1. Think of sampling points in I.
    – Consider the set 1NZ={nN:n∈Z}\tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}=\{\tfrac{n}{N}: n\in \mathbb{Z}\}N1​Z={Nn​:n∈Z}. These points “chop up” the real line into little increments of length 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​.
    – The expression #(I∩1NZ)\#(I \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z})#(I∩N1​Z) is simply the number of these chopped-up points that end up falling inside the interval III.

  2. Why divide by NNN?
    – Since each “chop” is of width 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​, if you want to approximate the length of III by the number of chops, you must multiply (or effectively “weight”) the count by that chop-size 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​.
    – Equivalently, dividing the count by NNN is the same as multiplying it by 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​. Hence
    1N #(I∩1NZ)  =  (1N)×(number of points of spacing 1N in I).\frac{1}{N}\,\#\bigl(I \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}\bigr)\;=\; \bigl(\tfrac{1}{N}\bigr)\times \bigl(\text{number of points of spacing } \tfrac{1}{N}\text{ in }I\bigr).N1​#(I∩N1​Z)=(N1​)×(number of points of spacing N1​ in I).

  3. Relation to a “ruler” analogy.
    – Imagine laying down a “ruler” marked only at the fractions 0N,1N,2N,…\tfrac{0}{N}, \tfrac{1}{N}, \tfrac{2}{N}, \dotsN0​,N1​,N2​,….
    – Counting how many marks of that ruler land in III and then multiplying by 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​ is analogous to measuring III using only these coarse marks.

  4. Why do we need a limit as N→∞N\to\inftyN→∞?
    – For small NNN, this coarse measurement might glancingly miss a bit of III near the edges or skip small gaps. But as NNN becomes larger, the marks become denser and the count becomes a better and better approximation of the actual length.
    – In the limit N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞, the quantity
    1N #(I∩1NZ)\tfrac{1}{N}\,\#\bigl(I \cap \tfrac{1}{N}\mathbb{Z}\bigr)N1​#(I∩N1​Z)
    converges to the exact length of III.

Thus, we are not literally equating “number of points” with “length”: rather, we count how many evenly spaced points of spacing 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​ fit in III, and then multiply that count by the spacing 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​. That product approximates the length of III. As the spacing 1N\tfrac{1}{N}N1​ goes to 000 (i.e., N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞), this approximation converges to the true length of III.

Given an interval III, define a box B=I1×I2×⋯ ,×IdB = I_1 \times I_2 \times \cdots, \times I_dB=I1​×I2​×⋯,×Id​. B∈RdB \in R^dB∈Rd
∣I∣=b−a|I| = b-a∣I∣=b−a when I=[ab],  (ab),  [ab),  (ab]I = [a b], \; (a b), \; [a b), \; (a b]I=[ab],(ab),[ab),(ab]. Similarly,
vol(B)=∣I1∣×∣I2∣×⋯×∣Id∣\text{vol}(B) = |I_1| \times |I_2| \times \cdots \times |I_d|vol(B)=∣I1​∣×∣I2​∣×⋯×∣Id​∣

Define an elementary set EEE to be the finite, disjoint union of boxes BBB as defined above.

the measure of EEE is given by m(E)m(E)m(E) is the sum of the volumes of the boxes of the disjoint partition.

Now consdier a general, bounded set SSS. Define the concept of Jordan measure of SSS using the measure of elementary sets.

Below is one common way to define the Jordan measure of a bounded set in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd, using the notion of elementary sets (finite unions of disjoint boxes):

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Elementary sets and their measure
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
  1. An (open/closed/half‐open) interval in R\mathbb{R}R has length
    ∣I∣  =  b−aifI  =  [ a,b ],   (a,b),   [ a,b),   (a,b ].|I| \;=\; b - a \quad \text{if} \quad I \;=\; [\,a,b\,],\;\,(a,b),\;\,[\,a,b),\;\,(a,b\,].∣I∣=b−aifI=[a,b],(a,b),[a,b),(a,b].
  2. A box B⊂RdB\subset \mathbb{R}^dB⊂Rd is a product of intervals:
    B  =  I1 × I2 × ⋯ × Id,B \;=\; I_1 \,\times\, I_2 \,\times\,\cdots\,\times\, I_d,B=I1​×I2​×⋯×Id​,
    where each Ik⊂RI_k\subset \mathbb{R}Ik​⊂R is an interval. The volume of such a box is
    vol(B)  =  ∣I1∣ × ∣I2∣ × ⋯× ∣Id∣.\mathrm{vol}(B) \;=\; |I_1| \,\times\, |I_2| \,\times\,\cdots\times\, |I_d|.vol(B)=∣I1​∣×∣I2​∣×⋯×∣Id​∣.
  3. An elementary set E⊂RdE\subset\mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd is a finite union of boxes that are pairwise disjoint:
    E  =  B1  ∪  B2  ∪  ⋯  ∪  Bn,Bi∩Bj=∅    (i≠j).E \;=\; B_1 \;\cup\; B_2 \;\cup\; \cdots \;\cup\; B_n, \quad B_i \cap B_j = \varnothing \;\;(i\neq j).E=B1​∪B2​∪⋯∪Bn​,Bi​∩Bj​=∅(i=j).
    The measure (or volume) of EEE is defined as the sum of the volumes of its boxes:
    m(E)  =  ∑i=1nvol(Bi).m(E) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^n \mathrm{vol}(B_i).m(E)=i=1∑n​vol(Bi​).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Outer and inner approximations by elementary sets
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Let S⊂RdS\subset \mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd be a bounded set. We approximate SSS from “above” and “below” by elementary sets:

• An elementary set EEE is called an outer approximation of SSS if S⊆ES \subseteq ES⊆E.
• An elementary set FFF is called an inner approximation of SSS if F⊆SF \subseteq SF⊆S.

Define:
• The outer (“upper”) measure of SSS by
m∗(S)  =  inf⁡{ m(E)  :  E is an elementary set and S⊆E}.m^*(S) \;=\; \inf \bigl\{\,m(E) \;:\; E \text{ is an elementary set and } S \subseteq E \bigr\}.m∗(S)=inf{m(E):E is an elementary set and S⊆E}.
• The inner (“lower”) measure of SSS by
m∗(S)  =  sup⁡{ m(F)  :  F is an elementary set and F⊆S}.m_*(S) \;=\; \sup \bigl\{\,m(F) \;:\; F \text{ is an elementary set and } F \subseteq S \bigr\}.m∗​(S)=sup{m(F):F is an elementary set and F⊆S}.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Jordan measurability and Jordan measure
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
We say that a bounded set S⊂RdS\subset\mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd is Jordan measurable if the outer and inner measures coincide:
m∗(S)  =  m∗(S).m^*(S) \;=\; m_*(S).m∗(S)=m∗​(S).
In that case, we define the Jordan measure of SSS (also called the Jordan content) to be this common value:
m(S)  =  m∗(S)  =  m∗(S).m(S) \;=\; m^*(S) \;=\; m_*(S).m(S)=m∗(S)=m∗​(S).

Intuitively:
• If you can cover SSS by some finite union of boxes (an elementary set) with total volume very close to some number LLL, and also fit inside SSS a disjoint union of boxes with total volume very close to the same number LLL, then that “squeezes” the measure of SSS to exactly LLL.
• If no matter how carefully you cover SSS from above and below by elementary sets, there remains a “gap” in the volumes, then SSS is not Jordan measurable.

Thus, for a bounded set S⊂RdS\subset \mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd, its Jordan measure (if it exists) is the unique value you get by approximating SSS from inside and outside by finite unions of boxes, and letting those approximations converge.

Let B∈RdB \in R^dB∈Rd be a closed box. Let f:B→Rf: B \to Rf:B→R be continuous. The set {(x,f(x):x∈B}∈Rd+1\{(x, f(x): x \in B\} \in R^{d+1}{(x,f(x):x∈B}∈Rd+1 is the graph of fff. Show that it is Jordan measurable.

Explanation:

We wish to show that if B⊂RdB \subset \mathbb{R}^dB⊂Rd is a closed box and f:B→Rf : B \to \mathbb{R}f:B→R is a continuous function, then the graph
G  =  {(x,f(x)):x∈B}  ⊂  Rd+1G \;=\; \bigl\{ (x, f(x)) : x \in B \bigr\} \;\subset\; \mathbb{R}^{d+1}G={(x,f(x)):x∈B}⊂Rd+1
is Jordan measurable in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1.

The key idea is that although GGG lives in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1, it is “only” ddd-dimensional in nature; as a result it occupies no (d+1)(d+1)(d+1)-dimensional volume, and one can cover it by boxes of arbitrarily small total volume. From the fundamental criterion for Jordan measurability in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1 (a bounded set is Jordan measurable if and only if its boundary has measure zero), it will follow that GGG has (d+1)(d+1)(d+1)-dimensional Jordan measure zero and hence is Jordan measurable.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. GGG is closed and bounded
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
  1. Since BBB is a closed box in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd, it is compact.
  2. Since fff is continuous on the compact set BBB, it is bounded and uniformly continuous on BBB. Hence {(x,f(x)):x∈B}\{ (x,f(x)) : x \in B\}{(x,f(x)):x∈B} is contained in a closed and bounded region in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1.
  3. The graph GGG is also a closed subset of Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1 (continuity of fff ensures that).

Hence G⊂Rd+1G\subset \mathbb{R}^{d+1}G⊂Rd+1 is closed and bounded.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Covering GGG with “thin pillars”
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
To show GGG has (d+1)(d+1)(d+1)-dimensional measure zero, we will cover it by sets (boxes in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1) whose total volume can be made arbitrarily small.

Because fff is uniformly continuous, given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that whenever ∥x−y∥<δ\|x - y\| < \delta∥x−y∥<δ in BBB, we have
∣ f(x)  −  f(y)∣<ε.\bigl|\,f(x)\;-\;f(y)\bigr| < \varepsilon.​f(x)−f(y)​<ε.
Now partition the box B⊂RdB\subset \mathbb{R}^dB⊂Rd into finitely many smaller boxes B1,B2,…,BnB_1, B_2, \dots, B_nB1​,B2​,…,Bn​ so that the diameter of each BiB_iBi​ is less than δ\deltaδ. Hence, within each BiB_iBi​, the function fff varies by no more than ε\varepsilonε.

For each such BiB_iBi​, consider its “vertical extension” or “pillar” in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1:
B^i  =  Bi×[ min⁡x∈Bif(x), max⁡x∈Bif(x)]  ⊂  Rd+1.\widehat{B}_i \;=\; B_i \times \bigl[\,\min_{x\in B_i}f(x),\,\max_{x\in B_i}f(x)\bigr] \;\subset\; \mathbb{R}^{d+1}.Bi​=Bi​×[x∈Bi​min​f(x),x∈Bi​max​f(x)]⊂Rd+1.
Because the oscillation of fff on BiB_iBi​ is at most ε\varepsilonε, we see
[min⁡x∈Bif(x), max⁡x∈Bif(x)]\bigl[\min_{x\in B_i}f(x),\,\max_{x\in B_i}f(x)\bigr][x∈Bi​min​f(x),x∈Bi​max​f(x)]
is an interval of length at most ε\varepsilonε. Thus each B^i\widehat{B}_iBi​ has volume
vol(B^i)  ≤  vol(Bi)  ×  ε.\mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widehat{B}_i\bigr) \;\le\; \mathrm{vol}\bigl(B_i\bigr) \;\times\; \varepsilon.vol(Bi​)≤vol(Bi​)×ε.
Since G∩(Bi×R)G\cap \bigl(B_i\times\mathbb{R}\bigr)G∩(Bi​×R) is contained in B^i\widehat{B}_iBi​, the union of these pillars covers GGG:
G  ⊆  ⋃i=1n B^i.G \;\subseteq\; \bigcup_{i=1}^n \,\widehat{B}_i.G⊆i=1⋃n​Bi​.

Hence,
vol(⋃i=1nB^i)  ≤  ∑i=1nvol(B^i)  ≤  ∑i=1n(vol(Bi)×ε)  =  ε∑i=1nvol(Bi).\mathrm{vol} \Bigl(\bigcup_{i=1}^n \widehat{B}_i\Bigr) \;\le\; \sum_{i=1}^n \mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widehat{B}_i\bigr) \;\le\; \sum_{i=1}^n \Bigl(\mathrm{vol}(B_i)\times \varepsilon\Bigr) \;=\; \varepsilon \sum_{i=1}^n \mathrm{vol}(B_i).vol(i=1⋃n​Bi​)≤i=1∑n​vol(Bi​)≤i=1∑n​(vol(Bi​)×ε)=εi=1∑n​vol(Bi​).
Since {Bi}\{B_i\}{Bi​} is just a partition of BBB, the sum of the vol(Bi)\mathrm{vol}(B_i)vol(Bi​) is vol(B)\mathrm{vol}(B)vol(B), a fixed finite number. We can make ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0 arbitrarily small, so:
∀ϵ>0:∃(cover of G by boxes of total volume <ϵ).\forall \epsilon>0: \quad \exists \Bigl(\text{cover of }G\text{ by boxes of total volume }< \epsilon\Bigr).∀ϵ>0:∃(cover of G by boxes of total volume <ϵ).
This implies GGG has Lebesgue (or Jordan) measure zero in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Conclusion: Jordan measurability
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
A bounded subset of Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1 of measure zero is automatically Jordan measurable, because its boundary is contained within itself (a set of measure zero) and thus also has measure zero. Concretely, for Jordan measurability we need that the set is bounded and that for every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, we can find an elementary set that covers GGG with volume <ε< \varepsilon<ε, and another elementary set contained in GGG of volume >−ε> -\varepsilon>−ε. But the second is trivial (take the empty set), and the first we saw how to construct.

Hence,
G  =  {(x,f(x)):x∈B}G \;=\; \bigl\{(x,f(x)): x\in B\bigr\}G={(x,f(x)):x∈B}
is Jordan measurable in Rd+1\mathbb{R}^{d+1}Rd+1. In fact, its Jordan measure (the (d+1)(d+1)(d+1)-dimensional “volume” of the hypersurface) is 000.

Let B(x,r):={y∈Rd:∣y−x∣<r}B(x,r) := \{y \in R^d: |y - x| < r \}B(x,r):={y∈Rd:∣y−x∣<r} be an open ball centered at x∈Rdx \in R^dx∈Rd. Show that it is Jordan measurable.

Explanation:

To show that an open ball
B(x,r)  =  { y∈Rd:∣y−x∣<r}B(x,r)\;=\;\bigl\{\,y\in\mathbb{R}^d : \lvert y - x\rvert < r\bigr\}B(x,r)={y∈Rd:∣y−x∣<r}
is Jordan measurable using only the notions of Jordan outer and inner measures, we must prove that
m∗(B(x,r))  =  m∗(B(x,r)).m^*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) \;=\; m_*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr).m∗(B(x,r))=m∗​(B(x,r)).
Recall:

• The Jordan outer measure of S⊂RdS\subset\mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd is
m∗(S)  =  inf⁡{m(E)  :  E is an elementary set and S⊆E}.m^*(S) \;=\; \inf \Bigl\{ m(E) \;:\; E \text{ is an elementary set and } S \subseteq E \Bigr\}.m∗(S)=inf{m(E):E is an elementary set and S⊆E}.
• The Jordan inner measure of S⊂RdS\subset\mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd is
m∗(S)  =  sup⁡{m(F)  :  F is an elementary set and F⊆S}.m_*(S) \;=\; \sup \Bigl\{ m(F) \;:\; F \text{ is an elementary set and } F \subseteq S \Bigr\}.m∗​(S)=sup{m(F):F is an elementary set and F⊆S}.
• A set SSS is called Jordan measurable if m∗(S)=m∗(S)m^*(S) = m_*(S)m∗(S)=m∗​(S). In that case, that common value is denoted by m(S)m(S)m(S).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Known volume of a ball
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    From geometry (or integration in spherical coordinates), one knows that the Lebesgue volume of a (closed or open) ball of radius rrr in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd is
    ωd rd,\omega_d\, r^d,ωd​rd,
    where ωd\omega_dωd​ is the volume of the unit ball in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd. Our aim is to show
    m∗(B(x,r))=m∗(B(x,r))=ωd rd.m^*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) = m_*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) = \omega_d\,r^d.m∗(B(x,r))=m∗​(B(x,r))=ωd​rd.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Outer measure ≤ ωdrd\omega_d r^dωd​rd + ε
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
We show that for every ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there is an elementary set Eε⊇B(x,r)E_\varepsilon \supseteq B(x,r)Eε​⊇B(x,r) whose total volume is less than ωdrd+ε\omega_d r^d + \varepsilonωd​rd+ε. Because m∗(B(x,r))m^*(B(x,r))m∗(B(x,r)) is the infimum of volumes of such covers, that will imply
m∗(B(x,r))  ≤  ωd rd.m^*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) \;\le\; \omega_d\,r^d.m∗(B(x,r))≤ωd​rd.

Step-by-step idea:

  1. Enclose the ball B(x,r)B(x,r)B(x,r) in a large coordinate-aligned box (for instance, a cube of side 2r2r2r centered at xxx).
  2. Subdivide that box into a fine grid of little cubes (of side length δ\deltaδ), so that (i) every cube that intersects B(x,r)B(x,r)B(x,r) is included in the cover; (ii) the cubes are disjoint in the interior and together form an elementary set.
  3. As δ→0\delta\to 0δ→0, the total volume of cubes that intersect the ball approaches ωdrd\omega_d r^dωd​rd from above. The error near the “boundary shell” of the ball can be made as small as desired by choosing sufficiently fine subdivisions.

This shows that for any ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, we can find an elementary set EεE_\varepsilonEε​ with
B(x,r)  ⊆  Eεandm(Eε)<ωdrd+ε.B(x,r)\;\subseteq\;E_\varepsilon \quad \text{and} \quad m\bigl(E_\varepsilon\bigr)<\omega_d r^d+\varepsilon.B(x,r)⊆Eε​andm(Eε​)<ωd​rd+ε.
Hence,
m∗(B(x,r))  =  inf⁡S⊃B(x,r) m(S)  ≤  ωd rd.m^*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr)\;=\;\inf_{S\supset B(x,r)}\,m(S)\;\le\;\omega_d\,r^d.m∗(B(x,r))=S⊃B(x,r)inf​m(S)≤ωd​rd.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Inner measure ≥ ωdrd\omega_d r^dωd​rd - ε
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
We similarly show that for every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, there is an elementary set Fε⊆B(x,r)F_\varepsilon \subseteq B(x,r)Fε​⊆B(x,r) whose total volume is at least ωdrd−ε\omega_d r^d - \varepsilonωd​rd−ε. Because m∗(B(x,r))m_*(B(x,r))m∗​(B(x,r)) is the supremum of volumes of such “inscribed” elementary sets, this implies
m∗(B(x,r))  ≥  ωd rd.m_*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) \;\ge\; \omega_d\,r^d.m∗​(B(x,r))≥ωd​rd.

One does almost the same subdivision, but now only keep those small cubes that fit entirely inside B(x,r)B(x,r)B(x,r). Very close to the boundary, you may have small cubes that partially stick out; you discard those. By letting the grid size go to zero, the total volume of cubes that lie wholly inside B(x,r)B(x,r)B(x,r) approaches ωdrd\omega_d r^dωd​rd from below. In symbols, for any ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, one can refine the grid so that an inscribed elementary set Fε⊂B(x,r)F_\varepsilon \subset B(x,r)Fε​⊂B(x,r) has

m(Fε)>ωd rd−ε.m\bigl(F_\varepsilon\bigr) > \omega_d\,r^d - \varepsilon.m(Fε​)>ωd​rd−ε.
Thus
m∗(B(x,r))  =  sup⁡F⊂B(x,r) m(F)  ≥  ωd rd.m_*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) \;=\; \sup_{F \subset B(x,r)}\,m(F) \;\ge\; \omega_d\,r^d.m∗​(B(x,r))=F⊂B(x,r)sup​m(F)≥ωd​rd.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Conclusion: Jordan measurability
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Combining these two inequalities,

• from above:
m∗(B(x,r))  ≤  ωd rd,\displaystyle m^*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr)\;\le\;\omega_d\,r^d,m∗(B(x,r))≤ωd​rd,

• from below:
m∗(B(x,r))  ≥  ωd rd,\displaystyle m_*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr)\;\ge\;\omega_d\,r^d,m∗​(B(x,r))≥ωd​rd,

forces
m∗(B(x,r))  =  m∗(B(x,r))  =  ωd rd.m^*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) \;=\; m_*\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr) \;=\; \omega_d\,r^d.m∗(B(x,r))=m∗​(B(x,r))=ωd​rd.
Hence B(x,r)B(x,r)B(x,r) is Jordan measurable, and its Jordan measure is exactly the usual volume ωd rd\omega_d\,r^dωd​rd.

Let S⊂RdS \subset R^dS⊂Rd be a bounded set. Let A,B⊂RdA, B \subset R^dA,B⊂Rd be elementary sets such that A⊂S⊂BA \subset S \subset BA⊂S⊂B and m(B∖A)≤ϵm(B \setminus A) \leq \epsilonm(B∖A)≤ϵ for every ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. This is equivalent to Jordan measurability of SSS. Prove this.

Explanation:

We wish to show that the following two statements about a bounded set S⊂RdS \subset \mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd are equivalent:

(1) SSS is Jordan measurable (i.e., m∗(S)=m∗(S)m^*(S) = m_*(S)m∗(S)=m∗​(S)), where
m∗(S)  =  inf⁡{m(E):E⊃S,  E is elementary},m∗(S)  =  sup⁡{m(F):F⊂S,  F is elementary}.m^*(S) \;=\; \inf\{m(E): E\supset S,\; E \text{ is elementary}\}, \quad m_*(S) \;=\; \sup\{m(F): F\subset S,\; F \text{ is elementary}\}.m∗(S)=inf{m(E):E⊃S,E is elementary},m∗​(S)=sup{m(F):F⊂S,F is elementary}.

(2) For every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, there exist elementary sets A,B⊂RdA,B\subset \mathbb{R}^dA,B⊂Rd such that
A  ⊂  S  ⊂  Bandm(B∖A)  ≤  ε.A \;\subset\; S \;\subset\; B \quad\text{and}\quad m\bigl(B\setminus A\bigr)\;\le\;\varepsilon.A⊂S⊂Bandm(B∖A)≤ε.

Below is a step‐by‐step proof of the equivalence.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
⇒ Direction (Jordan measurability implies the “ε-thin sandwich” property)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Assume SSS is Jordan measurable, so m∗(S)=m∗(S)m^*(S) = m_*(S)m∗(S)=m∗​(S). Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. We will construct elementary sets A⊂S⊂BA\subset S \subset BA⊂S⊂B such that m(B∖A)<εm(B \setminus A) < \varepsilonm(B∖A)<ε.

Step 1. Approximate SSS from below.
Since m∗(S)=sup⁡{m(F):F⊂S,  F elementary}m_*(S) = \sup\{ m(F) : F\subset S,\;F\text{ elementary}\}m∗​(S)=sup{m(F):F⊂S,F elementary}, there is an elementary set A⊂SA\subset SA⊂S so that
m(A)  >  m∗(S)−ε2.m(A) \;>\; m_*(S) - \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}.m(A)>m∗​(S)−2ε​.

Step 2. Approximate SSS from above.
Since m∗(S)=inf⁡{m(G):G⊃S,  G elementary}m^*(S) = \inf\{ m(G) : G\supset S,\;G\text{ elementary}\}m∗(S)=inf{m(G):G⊃S,G elementary}, there is an elementary set G⊃SG\supset SG⊃S so that
m(G)  <  m∗(S)+ε2.m(G) \;<\; m^*(S) + \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}.m(G)<m∗(S)+2ε​.

Step 3. Ensure A⊂GA \subset GA⊂G.
Usually one needs a small refinement step: replace GGG by an elementary set BBB such that A⊂B⊂GA\subset B\subset GA⊂B⊂G (if necessary, we can split boxes of GGG to include those from AAA, so that BBB and AAA fit together nicely). This does not increase the measure, so
m(B)  ≤  m(G)  <  m∗(S)+ε2.m(B)\;\le\;m(G) \;<\;m^*(S)+\tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}.m(B)≤m(G)<m∗(S)+2ε​.
Hence we have
A  ⊂  S  ⊂  B,A \;\subset\; S \;\subset\; B,A⊂S⊂B,
with AAA and BBB elemental.

Step 4. Estimate m(B∖A)m(B\setminus A)m(B∖A).
Since B∖A⊂BB\setminus A\subset BB∖A⊂B, we have
m(B∖A)  ≤  m(B)  −  m(A)  ≤  (m∗(S)+ε2)  −  (m∗(S)−ε2)  =  m∗(S)−m∗(S)+ε.m\bigl(B\setminus A\bigr) \;\le\; m(B) \;-\; m(A) \;\le\; \bigl(m^*(S) + \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}\bigr) \;-\; \bigl(m_*(S) - \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}\bigr) \;=\; m^*(S) - m_*(S) + \varepsilon.m(B∖A)≤m(B)−m(A)≤(m∗(S)+2ε​)−(m∗​(S)−2ε​)=m∗(S)−m∗​(S)+ε.
But for a Jordan measurable set, m∗(S)−m∗(S)=0m^*(S) - m_*(S)=0m∗(S)−m∗​(S)=0. Therefore
m(B∖A)  ≤  ε.m\bigl(B\setminus A\bigr) \;\le\; \varepsilon.m(B∖A)≤ε.
This shows that for every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, we found A,BA,BA,B elementary with A⊂S⊂BA\subset S\subset BA⊂S⊂B and m(B∖A)≤εm(B\setminus A)\le\varepsilonm(B∖A)≤ε.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
⇐ Direction (“ε-thin sandwich” property implies Jordan measurability)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Conversely, suppose that for each ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there are elementary sets
Aε  ⊂  S  ⊂  Bεwithm(Bε∖Aε)  ≤  ε.A_\varepsilon \;\subset\; S \;\subset\; B_\varepsilon \quad \text{with} \quad m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\setminus A_\varepsilon\bigr)\;\le\;\varepsilon.Aε​⊂S⊂Bε​withm(Bε​∖Aε​)≤ε.
We want to conclude SSS is Jordan measurable, i.e. m∗(S)=m∗(S)m^*(S) = m_*(S)m∗(S)=m∗​(S).

Step 1. Relation to inner and outer measures.
By definition:
m∗(S)  =  sup⁡{ m(F):F⊂S,  F is elementary}andm∗(S)  =  inf⁡{ m(G):G⊃S,  G is elementary}.m_*(S) \;=\; \sup\{\,m(F):F \subset S,\;F\text{ is elementary}\} \quad\text{and}\quad m^*(S) \;=\; \inf\{\,m(G):G \supset S,\;G\text{ is elementary}\}.m∗​(S)=sup{m(F):F⊂S,F is elementary}andm∗(S)=inf{m(G):G⊃S,G is elementary}.
Since Aε⊂S⊂BεA_\varepsilon \subset S\subset B_\varepsilonAε​⊂S⊂Bε​, we have
m∗(S)  ≥  m(Aε)andm∗(S)  ≤  m(Bε).m_*(S) \;\ge\; m\bigl(A_\varepsilon\bigr) \quad\text{and}\quad m^*(S) \;\le\; m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\bigr).m∗​(S)≥m(Aε​)andm∗(S)≤m(Bε​).
Hence
m∗(S)  −  m∗(S)  ≤  m(Bε)  −  m(Aε).m^*(S) \;-\; m_*(S) \;\le\; m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\bigr) \;-\; m\bigl(A_\varepsilon\bigr).m∗(S)−m∗​(S)≤m(Bε​)−m(Aε​).

Step 2. Relate m(Bε)−m(Aε)m(B_\varepsilon) - m(A_\varepsilon)m(Bε​)−m(Aε​) to m(Bε∖Aε)m(B_\varepsilon\setminus A_\varepsilon)m(Bε​∖Aε​).
In general for an elementary set Aε⊂BεA_\varepsilon\subset B_\varepsilonAε​⊂Bε​, we have
m(Bε)  −  m(Aε)  ≥  m(Bε∖Aε).m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\bigr) \;-\; m\bigl(A_\varepsilon\bigr) \;\ge\; m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\setminus A_\varepsilon\bigr).m(Bε​)−m(Aε​)≥m(Bε​∖Aε​).
(This inequality becomes an equality if both are unions of disjoint boxes and Aε⊂BεA_\varepsilon\subset B_\varepsilonAε​⊂Bε​ in a “compatible” way, but at least the “≥\ge≥” always holds.)

From our assumption,
m(Bε∖Aε)  ≤  ε.m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\setminus A_\varepsilon\bigr) \;\le\; \varepsilon.m(Bε​∖Aε​)≤ε.
Thus,
m∗(S)  −  m∗(S)  ≤  m(Bε)  −  m(Aε)  ≤  m(Bε∖Aε)  ≤  ε.m^*(S)\;-\;m_*(S) \;\le\; m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\bigr)\;-\;m\bigl(A_\varepsilon\bigr) \;\le\; m\bigl(B_\varepsilon\setminus A_\varepsilon\bigr) \;\le\; \varepsilon.m∗(S)−m∗​(S)≤m(Bε​)−m(Aε​)≤m(Bε​∖Aε​)≤ε.

Step 3. Conclude m∗(S)=m∗(S)m^*(S) = m_*(S)m∗(S)=m∗​(S).
Because ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0 was arbitrary, the above inequality implies
m∗(S)  −  m∗(S)  =  0,m^*(S)\;-\;m_*(S)\;=\;0,m∗(S)−m∗​(S)=0,
which is precisely the definition that SSS is Jordan measurable.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The two statements are therefore equivalent:
• “For every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, there are elementary sets Aε⊂S⊂BεA_\varepsilon \subset S\subset B_\varepsilonAε​⊂S⊂Bε​ with m(Bε∖Aε)≤εm(B_\varepsilon \setminus A_\varepsilon)\le \varepsilonm(Bε​∖Aε​)≤ε.”
• “SSS is Jordan measurable, i.e. m∗(S)=m∗(S)m^*(S) = m_*(S)m∗(S)=m∗​(S).”

Hence the proof is complete.

Let E⊂RdE \subset R^dE⊂Rd be a bounded set. and F⊂RdF \subset R^dF⊂Rd be an elementary set.
Show that m∗(E)=m∗(E∩F)+m∗(E∖F)m^*(E) = m^*(E \cap F) + m^*(E\setminus F)m∗(E)=m∗(E∩F)+m∗(E∖F) where m∗(⋅)m^*(\cdot)m∗(⋅) is the Jordan outer measure.

Below is a “direct‐from‐definitions” proof of
μ∗(E)  =  μ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F)\mu^*(E) \;=\; \mu^*\bigl(E \cap F\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(E \setminus F\bigr)μ∗(E)=μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)
for any bounded set E⊂RdE\subset\mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd and any elementary set F⊂RdF\subset\mathbb{R}^dF⊂Rd.
Here, μ∗( ⋅ )\mu^*(\,\cdot\,)μ∗(⋅) is the Jordan outer measure, defined by
μ∗(E)  =  inf⁡ ⁣{ μ(G):G⊃E,  G is elementary},\mu^*(E) \;=\; \inf\!\Bigl\{\,\mu(G):G\supset E,\;G\text{ is elementary}\Bigr\},μ∗(E)=inf{μ(G):G⊃E,G is elementary},
and μ( ⋅ )\mu(\,\cdot\,)μ(⋅) is the usual “volume” of an elementary set (finite union of boxes). We will avoid appealing to any “general outer‐measure subadditivity theorem,” using instead only the geometric additivity properties of the volume of elementary sets.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Terminology: “Elementary Set” and its Volume

• An elementary set in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd is a finite union of boxes, each box being a Cartesian product of closed intervals.
• The volume μ(G)\mu(G)μ(G) of an elementary set GGG is computed by summing the volumes of finitely many pairwise disjoint boxes that cover GGG. One shows directly that if G1,G2G_1,G_2G1​,G2​ are elementary, then
μ(G1∪G2)  ≤  μ(G1)  +  μ(G2),\mu\bigl(G_1\cup G_2\bigr) \;\le\; \mu(G_1) \;+\; \mu(G_2),μ(G1​∪G2​)≤μ(G1​)+μ(G2​),
simply by combining boxes and (if necessary) subdividing them into disjoint pieces.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Desired Equality

We want to prove that if E⊂RdE\subset\mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd is bounded and F⊂RdF\subset\mathbb{R}^dF⊂Rd is elementary, then the two disjoint sets E∩FE\cap FE∩F and E∖FE\setminus FE∖F satisfy
μ∗(E)  =  μ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F).\mu^*(E) \;=\; \mu^*\bigl(E \cap F\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(E \setminus F\bigr).μ∗(E)=μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F).
Note that E=(E∩F)∪(E∖F)E = \bigl(E\cap F\bigr)\cup \bigl(E\setminus F\bigr)E=(E∩F)∪(E∖F) is a disjoint union.

We split the proof into two inequalities:

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) First Inequality:
μ∗(E)≤μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F).\mu^*(E) ≤ \mu^*(E ∩ F) + μ*(E \setminus F).μ∗(E)≤μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F).

(a) Cover each piece separately.
• Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0.
• By definition of μ∗(E∩F)\mu^*(E\cap F)μ∗(E∩F), there is an elementary set G1⊃E∩FG_1\supset E\cap FG1​⊃E∩F with
μ(G1)  <  μ∗(E∩F)  +  ε2.\mu(G_1) \;<\; \mu^*(E\cap F) \;+\; \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}.μ(G1​)<μ∗(E∩F)+2ε​.
• Similarly, there is an elementary set G2⊃E∖FG_2\supset E\setminus FG2​⊃E∖F with
μ(G2)  <  μ∗(E∖F)  +  ε2.\mu(G_2) \;<\; \mu^*(E \setminus F) \;+\; \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}.μ(G2​)<μ∗(E∖F)+2ε​.

(b) Combine the covers.
• Note that E=(E∩F)∪(E∖F)⊂G1∪G2E = (E\cap F)\cup(E\setminus F) \subset G_1\cup G_2E=(E∩F)∪(E∖F)⊂G1​∪G2​.
• Set H=G1∪G2H=G_1\cup G_2H=G1​∪G2​. Since the union of two elementary sets is again elementary, HHH is an elementary set containing EEE. By definition of outer measure,
μ∗(E)  ≤  μ(H).\mu^*(E) \;\le\; \mu(H).μ∗(E)≤μ(H).

(c) Relate μ(H) to μ(G1) and μ(G2).
• Because G1G_1G1​ and G2G_2G2​ are each finite unions of boxes, one shows directly
μ(G1∪G2)  ≤  μ(G1)  +  μ(G2).\mu\bigl(G_1 \cup G_2\bigr) \;\le\; \mu(G_1) \;+\; \mu(G_2).μ(G1​∪G2​)≤μ(G1​)+μ(G2​).
(This follows from decomposing the union into disjoint boxes, or, more simply, from the fact that elementary‐set “volume” satisfies finite subadditivity.)

(d) Putting it together.
Consequently,

μ∗(E)  ≤  μ(H)=μ(G1∪G2)  ≤  μ(G1)+μ(G2)  <  (μ∗(E∩F)+ε2)+(μ∗(E∖F)+ε2).\mu^*(E) \; \le \; \mu(H) = \mu\bigl(G_1 \cup G_2\bigr) \;\le\; \mu(G_1) + \mu(G_2) \;<\; \Bigl(\mu^*(E\cap F) + \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}\Bigr) + \Bigl(\mu^*(E\setminus F) + \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}\Bigr).μ∗(E)≤μ(H)=μ(G1​∪G2​)≤μ(G1​)+μ(G2​)<(μ∗(E∩F)+2ε​)+(μ∗(E∖F)+2ε​).
Hence,
μ∗(E)  <  μ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F)  +  ε.\mu^*(E) \;<\; \mu^*(E\cap F) \;+\; \mu^*(E\setminus F) \;+\; \varepsilon.μ∗(E)<μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)+ε.
• Letting ε→0\varepsilon\to 0ε→0, we obtain
μ∗(E)  ≤  μ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F).\mu^*(E) \;\le\; \mu^*\bigl(E \cap F\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(E \setminus F\bigr).μ∗(E)≤μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Second Inequality:
μ*(E) ≥ μ*(E ∩ F) + μ*(E \setminus F).

(a) Cover EEE as a whole.
• Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. By definition of μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E), there is an elementary G⊃EG\supset EG⊃E with
μ(G)  <  μ∗(E)+ε.\mu(G) \;<\; \mu^*(E) + \varepsilon.μ(G)<μ∗(E)+ε.

(b) Enclose each piece inside G.
• Clearly, E∩F  ⊂  G∩FE\cap F \;\subset\; G\cap FE∩F⊂G∩F and E∖F  ⊂  G∖F.E\setminus F\;\subset\; G\setminus F.E∖F⊂G∖F.
• Then by monotonicity of outer‐measure cover,
μ∗(E∩F)  ≤  μ(G∩F),μ∗(E∖F)  ≤  μ(G∖F).\mu^*\bigl(E\cap F\bigr) \;\le\; \mu\bigl(G\cap F\bigr), \quad \mu^*\bigl(E\setminus F\bigr) \;\le\; \mu\bigl(G\setminus F\bigr).μ∗(E∩F)≤μ(G∩F),μ∗(E∖F)≤μ(G∖F).

(c) Additivity on disjoint parts

Observe that G∩FG\cap FG∩F and G∖FG\setminus FG∖F are disjoint elementary sets whose union is GGG. Therefore
μ(G)=μ(G∩F)+μ(G∖F).\mu(G) = \mu\bigl(G\cap F\bigr) + \mu\bigl(G\setminus F\bigr).μ(G)=μ(G∩F)+μ(G∖F).

(d) Conclude.
• Summing the two inequalities in (b) and using the above partition of GGG:
μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)  ≤  μ(G∩F)+μ(G∖F)=μ(G)  <  μ∗(E)+ε.\mu^*\bigl(E\cap F\bigr) + \mu^*\bigl(E\setminus F\bigr) \;\le\; \mu\bigl(G\cap F\bigr) + \mu\bigl(G\setminus F\bigr) = \mu(G) \;<\; \mu^*(E) + \varepsilon.μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)≤μ(G∩F)+μ(G∖F)=μ(G)<μ∗(E)+ε.
• Letting ε→0\varepsilon \to 0ε→0 yields
μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)  ≤  μ∗(E).\mu^*\bigl(E\cap F\bigr) + \mu^*\bigl(E\setminus F\bigr) \;\le\; \mu^*(E).μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)≤μ∗(E).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Combine Both Inequalities

From steps (3) and (4), we have
μ∗(E)  ≤  μ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F)andμ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F)  ≤  μ∗(E).\mu^*(E) \;\le\; \mu^*\bigl(E \cap F\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(E \setminus F\bigr) \quad\text{and}\quad \mu^*\bigl(E \cap F\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(E \setminus F\bigr) \;\le\; \mu^*(E).μ∗(E)≤μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)andμ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F)≤μ∗(E).
Hence
μ∗(E)  =  μ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F),\mu^*(E) \;=\; \mu^*\bigl(E \cap F\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(E \setminus F\bigr),μ∗(E)=μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F),
and the proof is complete—without ever invoking a “general subadditivity property of outer measures.” Instead, we used only:

• The definition of μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) as an infimum of μ(G)\mu(G)μ(G) over elementary covers GGG.
• The fact that the measure μ( ⋅ )\mu(\,\cdot\,)μ(⋅) of an elementary set is finite‐additive over disjoint unions and is ≤‐additive (i.e.\ μ(G1∪G2)≤μ(G1)+μ(G2)\mu(G_1\cup G_2)\le \mu(G_1)+\mu(G_2)μ(G1​∪G2​)≤μ(G1​)+μ(G2​)) for two elementary sets G1,G2G_1,G_2G1​,G2​.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary:

For any bounded set EEE in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd and any elementary set FFF, the Jordan outer measure satisfies
μ∗(E)  =  μ∗(E∩F)  +  μ∗(E∖F).\mu^*(E) \;=\; \mu^*\bigl(E \cap F\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(E \setminus F\bigr).μ∗(E)=μ∗(E∩F)+μ∗(E∖F).
Both directions of the proof follow directly from the definition of μ∗\mu^*μ∗ and the basic geometry of finite unions of boxes (i.e.\ elementary sets). This does not require invoking the usual “outer‐measure subadditivity theorem,” but only the simpler statement that
μ(G1∪G2)≤μ(G1)+μ(G2)\mu(G_1 \cup G_2)\le \mu(G_1)+\mu(G_2)μ(G1​∪G2​)≤μ(G1​)+μ(G2​)
for elementary G1,G2G_1,G_2G1​,G2​.

Darboux and Riemann Integral

Piecewise constant Integral

Let f:[a    b]→Rf: [a \; \; b] \to Rf:[ab]→R be a bounded, piecewise constant (p.c.) function on a finite partition I1,⋯ ,InI_1, \cdots, I_nI1​,⋯,In​ of [a    b][a \; \; b][ab]. Let cic_ici​ be the value of the function on the interval IiI_iIi​. Then, the sum ∑ici∣Ii∣\sum_i c_i |I_i|∑i​ci​∣Ii​∣ is defined to be the real number denoted as p.c.∫abf(x)dx\text{p.c.} \int_a^b f(x) dxp.c.∫ab​f(x)dx and we will refer to it as the piecewise constant (p.c.) integral.

Prove the following properties:

  • Linearity
  • Monotonicity
  • any other relevant property

Setup:\textbf{Setup:}Setup:
Let [a,b]⊂R[a,b]\subset \mathbb{R}[a,b]⊂R be a closed and bounded interval. Suppose we have a finite partition
P:a=x0<x1<x2<⋯<xn−1<xn=b,P:\quad a = x_0 < x_1 < x_2 < \cdots < x_{n-1} < x_n = b,P:a=x0​<x1​<x2​<⋯<xn−1​<xn​=b,
and define the subintervals
Ik  =  [ xk−1, xk ],k=1,…,n.I_k \;=\; [\,x_{k-1},\,x_k\,],\quad k=1,\dots,n.Ik​=[xk−1​,xk​],k=1,…,n.
A function f:[a,b]→Rf:[a,b]\to \mathbb{R}f:[a,b]→R is called piecewise constant on PPP (or just “p.c. on [a,b][a,b][a,b]” if the partition is understood) if there exist constants ck∈Rc_k\in \mathbb{R}ck​∈R such that
f(x)  =  ckfor all x∈(xk−1, xk),k=1,…,n.f(x) \;=\; c_k \quad\text{for all }x\in (x_{k-1},\, x_k), \quad k=1,\dots,n.f(x)=ck​for all x∈(xk−1​,xk​),k=1,…,n.
(We do not care about the values of fff at the partition endpoints.)

The “piecewise constant (p.c.) integral” of fff over [a,b][a,b][a,b] is defined by
p.c.∫abf(x) dx  :=  ∑k=1nck ∣ Ik∣  =  ∑k=1nck (xk−xk−1).\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \;:=\; \sum_{k=1}^{n} c_k \,\bigl|\,I_k\bigr| \;=\; \sum_{k=1}^n c_k \,\bigl(x_k - x_{k-1}\bigr).p.c.∫ab​f(x)dx:=k=1∑n​ck​​Ik​​=k=1∑n​ck​(xk​−xk−1​).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Linearity
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Claim: p.c.∫ab(αf(x)+βg(x)) dx  =  α p.c.∫abf(x) dx  +  β p.c.∫abg(x) dx,\textbf{Claim: } \quad \mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b \bigl(\alpha f(x) + \beta g(x)\bigr)\,dx \;=\; \alpha\,\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \;+\;\beta\,\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b g(x)\,dx,Claim: p.c.∫ab​(αf(x)+βg(x))dx=αp.c.∫ab​f(x)dx+βp.c.∫ab​g(x)dx,
for any real scalars α,β\alpha,\betaα,β and piecewise constant functions f,gf,gf,g.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
∙\bullet∙ Proof idea.\textit{Proof idea.}Proof idea.

Without loss of generality, refine the partition (if necessary) so that both fff and ggg are piecewise constant on the same partition PPP. That is, there exist constants ck,dk∈Rc_k,d_k\in\mathbb{R}ck​,dk​∈R such that
f(x)=ck,g(x)=dkfor x∈(xk−1,xk),k=1,…,n.f(x) = c_k,\quad g(x)=d_k \quad\text{for }x\in (x_{k-1},x_k), \quad k=1,\dots,n.f(x)=ck​,g(x)=dk​for x∈(xk−1​,xk​),k=1,…,n.

For h(x):=αf(x)+βg(x)h(x) := \alpha f(x)+\beta g(x)h(x):=αf(x)+βg(x), we have h(x)=αck+βdkh(x)=\alpha c_k+\beta d_kh(x)=αck​+βdk​ when x∈(xk−1,xk)x\in (x_{k-1},x_k)x∈(xk−1​,xk​). Then by definition:
p.c.∫abh(x) dx  =  ∑k=1n(αck+βdk) (xk−xk−1).\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b h(x)\,dx \;=\; \sum_{k=1}^n \bigl(\alpha c_k + \beta d_k\bigr)\,\bigl(x_k - x_{k-1}\bigr).p.c.∫ab​h(x)dx=k=1∑n​(αck​+βdk​)(xk​−xk−1​).
Meanwhile,
α p.c.∫abf(x) dx  +  β p.c.∫abg(x) dx  =  α∑k=1nck ∣Ik∣  +  β∑k=1ndk ∣Ik∣.\alpha\,\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \;+\;\beta\,\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b g(x)\,dx \;=\; \alpha\sum_{k=1}^n c_k\,|I_k| \;+\; \beta\sum_{k=1}^n d_k\,|I_k|.αp.c.∫ab​f(x)dx+βp.c.∫ab​g(x)dx=αk=1∑n​ck​∣Ik​∣+βk=1∑n​dk​∣Ik​∣.
Factoring out ∑k=1n(xk−xk−1)\sum_{k=1}^n (x_k-x_{k-1})∑k=1n​(xk​−xk−1​), these are exactly the same sum. Thus
p.c.∫ab(αf+βg)  =  α p.c.∫abf  +  β p.c.∫abg.\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b \bigl(\alpha f + \beta g\bigr) \;=\; \alpha\,\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f \;+\;\beta\,\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b g.p.c.∫ab​(αf+βg)=αp.c.∫ab​f+βp.c.∫ab​g.

Hence linearity holds.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Monotonicity
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Claim: If f(x)≤g(x) for all x∈[a,b], then p.c.∫abf(x) dx  ≤  p.c.∫abg(x) dx.\textbf{Claim: } \quad \text{If }f(x)\le g(x)\text{ for all }x\in [a,b], \text{ then } \mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \;\le\; \mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b g(x)\,dx.Claim: If f(x)≤g(x) for all x∈[a,b], then p.c.∫ab​f(x)dx≤p.c.∫ab​g(x)dx.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
∙\bullet∙ Proof idea.\textit{Proof idea.}Proof idea.

Again, we use a common partition PPP. Suppose on each interval (xk−1,xk)(x_{k-1},x_k)(xk−1​,xk​), f(x)=ck≤dk=g(x)f(x)=c_k\le d_k=g(x)f(x)=ck​≤dk​=g(x). Then
p.c.∫abf(x) dx = ∑k=1nck (xk−xk−1),p.c.∫abg(x) dx = ∑k=1ndk (xk−xk−1).\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \,=\, \sum_{k=1}^n c_k\,\bigl(x_k-x_{k-1}\bigr), \quad \mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b g(x)\,dx \,=\, \sum_{k=1}^n d_k\,\bigl(x_k-x_{k-1}\bigr).p.c.∫ab​f(x)dx=k=1∑n​ck​(xk​−xk−1​),p.c.∫ab​g(x)dx=k=1∑n​dk​(xk​−xk−1​).
Because ck≤dkc_k\le d_kck​≤dk​ for each kkk and (xk−xk−1)≥0\bigl(x_k-x_{k-1}\bigr)\ge0(xk​−xk−1​)≥0, each summand of the first sum is at most the corresponding summand of the second sum. Hence
∑k=1nck (xk−xk−1)  ≤  ∑k=1ndk (xk−xk−1).\sum_{k=1}^n c_k\,\bigl(x_k-x_{k-1}\bigr) \;\le\; \sum_{k=1}^n d_k\,\bigl(x_k-x_{k-1}\bigr).k=1∑n​ck​(xk​−xk−1​)≤k=1∑n​dk​(xk​−xk−1​).
That is,
p.c.∫abf  ≤  p.c.∫abg.\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f \;\le\;\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b g.p.c.∫ab​f≤p.c.∫ab​g.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Additional Relevant Properties
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Here are a few other natural properties of the piecewise constant integral:

————————————————————————————
(a) Positivity:
If f(x)≥0f(x)\ge 0f(x)≥0 on [a,b][a,b][a,b], then
p.c.∫abf(x) dx  ≥  0.\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \;\ge\; 0.p.c.∫ab​f(x)dx≥0.
Indeed, if each constant value ck≥0c_k\ge0ck​≥0, then each term ck ∣Ik∣≥0c_k\,|I_k|\ge0ck​∣Ik​∣≥0, so their sum is nonnegative.

————————————————————————————
(b) Additivity (or “interval additivity”):
If c∈(a,b)c\in(a,b)c∈(a,b), then
p.c.∫abf(x) dx  =  p.c.∫acf(x) dx  +  p.c.∫cbf(x) dx.\mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \;=\; \mathrm{p.c.}\int_a^c f(x)\,dx \;+\; \mathrm{p.c.}\int_c^b f(x)\,dx.p.c.∫ab​f(x)dx=p.c.∫ac​f(x)dx+p.c.∫cb​f(x)dx.
Proof sketch: If one has a partition of [a,b][a,b][a,b], simply split it at the point ccc. Then the sum of the intervals from aaa to ccc plus the sum from ccc to bbb exactly reproduces the sum from aaa to bbb.

————————————————————————————
(c) Refinement invariance:
If PPP and QQQ are two finite partitions of [a,b][a,b][a,b] such that fff is piecewise constant with respect to both (i.e.\ constant on each subinterval of both partitions), then the p.c. integral yields the same sum.
In other words, if we refine the partition PPP to get a finer partition QQQ, the computed sums are identical.
(This follows directly from the definition, since the function takes the same constant value over all sub-subintervals.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary:\textbf{Summary:}Summary:

  1. p.c.∫\mathrm{p.c.}\intp.c.∫ is linear.
  2. If f≤gf\le gf≤g, then p.c.∫f≤p.c.∫g\mathrm{p.c.}\int f \le \mathrm{p.c.}\int gp.c.∫f≤p.c.∫g (monotonicity).
  3. p.c.∫\mathrm{p.c.}\intp.c.∫ is positive, additive over adjacent intervals, and independent of any subdivision refinements—properties mirroring those of the usual Riemann (and Lebesgue) integrals, but here proven more simply due to the piecewise constant setup.

Upper, Lower Darboux integral

Below is a step‐by‐step explanation of how to define the upper and lower Darboux integrals for a bounded function on [a,b][a,b][a,b], and how these definitions lead to the Darboux (Riemann–Darboux) integral.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Setup: Bounded Functions on a Closed Interval
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let f ⁣:[a,b]→Rf\colon [a,b]\to \mathbb{R}f:[a,b]→R be a bounded function. Being bounded means there is some M>0M>0M>0 such that ∣f(x)∣≤M\lvert f(x)\rvert \le M∣f(x)∣≤M for all x∈[a,b]x\in [a,b]x∈[a,b]. We wish to define the integral of fff over [a,b][a,b][a,b] in the sense of Darboux.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Partitions of [a,b]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A finite partition PPP of the interval [a,b][a,b][a,b] is a sequence of points
P:a=x0<x1<x2<⋯<xn−1<xn=b.P:\quad a = x_0 < x_1 < x_2 < \cdots < x_{n-1} < x_n = b.P:a=x0​<x1​<x2​<⋯<xn−1​<xn​=b.
The subintervals determined by PPP are
[xk−1, xk],k=1,2,…,n.[x_{k-1},\,x_k], \quad k=1,2,\ldots,n.[xk−1​,xk​],k=1,2,…,n.
We will write Δk=xk−xk−1\Delta_k = x_k - x_{k-1}Δk​=xk​−xk−1​ for the length of the kkk-th subinterval.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Upper and Lower Sums
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For a given partition PPP of [a,b][a,b][a,b] and a bounded function fff, define:

• On each subinterval Ik:=[xk−1,xk]I_k := [x_{k-1},x_k]Ik​:=[xk−1​,xk​], let
Mk  :=  sup⁡x∈Ik f(x),mk  :=  inf⁡x∈Ik f(x).M_k \;:=\; \sup_{x \in I_k}\,f(x), \quad m_k \;:=\; \inf_{x \in I_k}\,f(x).Mk​:=x∈Ik​sup​f(x),mk​:=x∈Ik​inf​f(x).
(Because fff is bounded, each of these suprema and infima is a finite real number.)

• The upper Darboux sum of fff with respect to PPP is
U(P,f)  =  ∑k=1nMk Δk,whereΔk=xk − xk−1.U(P,f) \;=\; \sum_{k=1}^n M_k\,\Delta_k, \quad\text{where}\quad \Delta_k = x_k \,-\, x_{k-1}.U(P,f)=k=1∑n​Mk​Δk​,whereΔk​=xk​−xk−1​.
• The lower Darboux sum of fff with respect to PPP is
L(P,f)  =  ∑k=1nmk Δk.L(P,f) \;=\; \sum_{k=1}^n m_k\,\Delta_k.L(P,f)=k=1∑n​mk​Δk​.

Geometrically, you can think of U(P,f)U(P,f)U(P,f) as the total area of rectangles lying above the graph of fff, with heights given by the supremum on each interval, while L(P,f)L(P,f)L(P,f) is the total area of rectangles lying below the graph, with heights given by the infimum.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Upper and Lower Darboux Integrals
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

To incorporate the idea behind “infimum of upper sums” and “supremum of lower sums,” we define:

• The upper Darboux integral:
∫ab‾f  :=  inf⁡P U(P,f),\overline{\int_a^b} f \;:=\; \inf_{P} \,U(P,f),∫ab​​f:=Pinf​U(P,f),
where the infimum is taken over all finite partitions PPP of [a,b][a,b][a,b].

• The lower Darboux integral:
∫ab‾f  :=  sup⁡P L(P,f),\underline{\int_a^b} f \;:=\; \sup_{P} \,L(P,f),∫ab​​f:=Psup​L(P,f),
where the supremum is taken over all finite partitions PPP of [a,b][a,b][a,b].

Since every L(P,f)L(P,f)L(P,f) must be at most every U(Q,f)U(Q,f)U(Q,f) (for any partitions P,QP,QP,Q), it follows that
∫ab‾f  ≤  ∫ab‾f.\underline{\int_a^b} f \;\le\; \overline{\int_a^b} f.∫ab​​f≤∫ab​​f.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Darboux (Riemann–Darboux) Integrable Functions
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A function fff is said to be (Darboux) integrable on [a,b][a,b][a,b] if and only if the upper and lower Darboux integrals coincide, viz.
∫ab‾f  =  ∫ab‾f.\underline{\int_a^b} f \;=\; \overline{\int_a^b} f.∫ab​​f=∫ab​​f.
When this happens, we define the common value:
∫abf(x) dx  :=  ∫ab‾f  =  ∫ab‾f.\int_{a}^b f(x)\,dx \;:=\; \underline{\int_a^b} f \;=\; \overline{\int_a^b} f.∫ab​f(x)dx:=∫ab​​f=∫ab​​f.
This quantity ∫abf(x) dx\int_{a}^b f(x)\,dx∫ab​f(x)dx is called the (Darboux) integral of fff over [a,b][a,b][a,b].

Thus, the “Darboux integral” of fff is precisely the real number III such that for every ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0, there is a partition PPP of [a,b][a,b][a,b] where the upper sum U(P,f)U(P,f)U(P,f) and the lower sum L(P,f)L(P,f)L(P,f) differ by less than ϵ\epsilonϵ, i.e.
U(P,f)  −  L(P,f)  <  ϵ.U(P,f)\;-\;L(P,f) \;<\; \epsilon.U(P,f)−L(P,f)<ϵ.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
6) Connection to “Piecewise Constant” Sums
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The logic of Darboux sums and the p.c. (piecewise constant) integrals share a similar approach:

• In the piecewise constant scenario, one literally takes the function to be constant on each interval, hence the integral is just a sum of “height ×\times× width”.
• In the Darboux approach, one uses suprema and infima of the function on each subinterval (rather than a single chosen value) and then refines partitions to home in on the actual integral.

If a function is integrable in the Darboux sense, then there exist partitions on which the upper and lower sums are arbitrarily close; equivalently, one can approximate fff arbitrarily well by piecewise constant functions whose integrals match that of fff.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. A partition P: a=x0<x1<⋯<xn=bP:\,a=x_0<x_1<\dots<x_n=bP:a=x0​<x1​<⋯<xn​=b is used to split [a,b][a,b][a,b] into subintervals.
  2. For a bounded fff, define:
    – Mk=sup⁡x∈[xk−1,xk]f(x)M_k = \sup_{x\in[x_{k-1},x_k]} f(x)Mk​=supx∈[xk−1​,xk​]​f(x),
    – mk=inf⁡x∈[xk−1,xk]f(x)m_k = \inf_{x\in[x_{k-1},x_k]} f(x)mk​=infx∈[xk−1​,xk​]​f(x).
    Then
    – Upper sum: U(P,f)=∑k=1nMk(xk−xk−1)U(P,f)=\sum_{k=1}^n M_k(x_k-x_{k-1})U(P,f)=∑k=1n​Mk​(xk​−xk−1​).
    – Lower sum: L(P,f)=∑k=1nmk(xk−xk−1)L(P,f)=\sum_{k=1}^n m_k(x_k-x_{k-1})L(P,f)=∑k=1n​mk​(xk​−xk−1​).
  3. The upper (resp.\ lower) Darboux integral is the infimum (resp.\ supremum) of U(P,f)U(P,f)U(P,f) (resp.\ L(P,f)L(P,f)L(P,f)) over all partitions PPP.
  4. If these two “extreme” integrals coincide, that common value is taken to be ∫abf\int_a^b f∫ab​f. This is the Darboux integral of fff over [a,b][a,b][a,b]. If they do not coincide, fff is not (Darboux) integrable.

Hence, the Darboux integral is built out of the same conceptual approach as the piecewise constant integral, but allowing suprema and infima to capture “tightest” upper and lower approximations on each interval, yielding a criterion for integrability via the equality of these infimum/supremum sums.

Riemann integral

Now, define Riemann integral of fff as before, using the ideas of a tagged partition of [a    b][a \; \; b][ab] and Riemann sums.

Below is a short, step-by-step explanation of how to define the Riemann integral of a bounded function on [a,b][a,b][a,b] using tagged partitions and Riemann sums. This builds on the earlier ideas of piecewise-constant integrals and Darboux sums, but now uses “tags” to evaluate fff at some chosen point in each subinterval.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Bounded Functions
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let f:[a,b]→Rf:[a,b]\to \mathbb{R}f:[a,b]→R be bounded. That is, there exists M>0M>0M>0 with ∣f(x)∣≤M\lvert f(x)\rvert \le M∣f(x)∣≤M for all x∈[a,b]x \in [a,b]x∈[a,b].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Partitions and Tagged Partitions
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A finite partition PPP of [a,b][a,b][a,b] is given by
P:  a=x0<x1<⋯<xn=b.P:\; a = x_0 < x_1 < \dots < x_n = b.P:a=x0​<x1​<⋯<xn​=b.
We write the subintervals as
Ik=[xk−1,xk],k=1,…,n.I_k = [x_{k-1}, x_k],\quad k=1,\dots, n.Ik​=[xk−1​,xk​],k=1,…,n.

A tagged partition is a partition PPP together with a choice of a “tag” τk∈Ik\tau_k \in I_kτk​∈Ik​ (often one requires τk∈[xk−1,xk]\tau_k \in [x_{k-1}, x_k]τk​∈[xk−1​,xk​]) for each kkk. Denote this by (P,T)(P,T)(P,T), where T={τ1,…,τn}T = \{\tau_1,\dots,\tau_n\}T={τ1​,…,τn​} with τk∈Ik\tau_k \in I_kτk​∈Ik​.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Riemann Sums
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Given a tagged partition (P,T)(P,T)(P,T), we form the Riemann sum of fff as follows:
Sf((P,T))  =  ∑k=1nf(τk) (xk−xk−1).S_f\bigl((P,T)\bigr) \;=\; \sum_{k=1}^n f(\tau_k)\,\bigl(x_k - x_{k-1}\bigr).Sf​((P,T))=k=1∑n​f(τk​)(xk​−xk−1​).
Here:
• τk\tau_kτk​ is the chosen tag in the subinterval [xk−1,xk][x_{k-1},x_k][xk−1​,xk​].
• xk−xk−1x_k - x_{k-1}xk​−xk−1​ is the length of that subinterval.

Intuitively, each term f(τk) (xk−xk−1)f(\tau_k)\,(x_k - x_{k-1})f(τk​)(xk​−xk−1​) represents the area of a rectangle of base [xk−1,xk][x_{k-1}, x_k][xk−1​,xk​] and height given by the function value at the tag.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Mesh (Norm) of a Partition
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The mesh (or norm) of a partition PPP is the length of the largest subinterval in PPP:
∥P∥  =  max⁡{ xk−xk−1  ⁣: k=1,…,n}.\|P\| \;=\; \max\{\,x_k - x_{k-1} \,\colon\, k=1,\dots,n\}.∥P∥=max{xk​−xk−1​:k=1,…,n}.
When we make ∥P∥\|P\|∥P∥ very small, it means we are “refining” the partition to get many small subintervals.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Definition of the Riemann Integral
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We say fff is Riemann integrable on [a,b][a,b][a,b] if there exists a number L∈RL \in \mathbb{R}L∈R such that for every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, there is a δ>0\delta>0δ>0 with the following property:

• For any tagged partition (P,T)(P,T)(P,T) of [a,b][a,b][a,b] whose mesh ∥P∥\|P\|∥P∥ is less than δ\deltaδ, we have
∣ Sf((P,T))  −  L ∣  <  ε.\Bigl\lvert\, S_f\bigl((P,T)\bigr) \;-\; L\,\Bigr\rvert \;<\; \varepsilon.​Sf​((P,T))−L​<ε.

If such an LLL exists, then we say fff is (Riemann) integrable on [a,b][a,b][a,b], and we write
∫abf(x) dx  =  L.\int_a^b f(x)\,dx \;=\; L.∫ab​f(x)dx=L.
Equivalently, one says that ∫abf(x) dx\int_a^b f(x)\,dx∫ab​f(x)dx is the limit of the Riemann sums Sf((P,T))S_f((P,T))Sf​((P,T)) as the mesh of the partition goes to zero.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
6) Why This Matches Darboux and Piecewise Constant Ideas
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• If the function is integrable in the Riemann sense, one can show that the upper and lower Darboux integrals coincide (and vice versa). Hence, the Riemann integral is the same as the Darboux integral.
• In many elementary cases (e.g.\ step functions, continuous functions on [a,b][a,b][a,b]), one explicitly sees that as partitions get finer, the Riemann sums approach a unique limit and agree with the area under the curve.
• The piecewise constant (p.c.) integrals are precisely the special case where each Riemann sum is formed by choosing exactly the constant value of fff on each subinterval. That leads to the same concept of “area under the graph,” now formalized by taking finer partitions and letting the mesh go to zero.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. A tagged partition (P,T)(P,T)(P,T) of [a,b][a,b][a,b] consists of a partition PPP and a choice of tags τk\tau_kτk​ in each subinterval.
  2. The Riemann sum is ∑k=1nf(τk)(xk−xk−1)\sum_{k=1}^n f(\tau_k)(x_k-x_{k-1})∑k=1n​f(τk​)(xk​−xk−1​).
  3. As the mesh of (P,T)(P,T)(P,T) goes to zero, if all these Riemann sums converge to the same real number LLL, then we say fff is Riemann integrable and define ∫abf=L\int_a^b f=L∫ab​f=L.
  4. This Riemann integral is consistent with the Darboux approach and the piecewise constant integrals, tying all viewpoints together.

Riemann and Darboux in RdR^dRd

Thus far we have dealt with the situation where f:[a    b]→Rf: [a \; \; b] \to Rf:[ab]→R. When we have the case f:U→Rf: U \to Rf:U→R where U⊂RdU \subset R^dU⊂Rd and UUU is bounded, how to extend the ideas of Darboux and Riemann integrals that we discussed thus far in one dimension.

Extending Darboux and Riemann Integrals from 1D to Higher Dimensions\textbf{Extending Darboux and Riemann Integrals from 1D to Higher Dimensions}Extending Darboux and Riemann Integrals from 1D to Higher Dimensions

When we move from a function f:[a,b]→Rf: [a,b] \to \mathbb{R}f:[a,b]→R in one dimension to a function f:U→Rf : U \to \mathbb{R}f:U→R with U⊂RdU \subset \mathbb{R}^dU⊂Rd bounded, the core ideas—subdivision of the domain, infimum/supremum for Darboux sums, and sample‐point (“tagged”) sums for Riemann sums—remain the same. The main difference is that we now partition a region in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd into small “boxes” (or “subrectangles”) instead of small intervals. Below is a concise overview.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Setup: A Bounded Domain in ℝᵈ
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Let U⊂RdU \subset \mathbb{R}^dU⊂Rd be bounded. That means there is a large rectangle
R  =  [a1,b1]×[a2,b2]×⋯×[ad,bd]R \;=\; [a_1, b_1]\times [a_2, b_2]\times \cdots \times [a_d, b_d]R=[a1​,b1​]×[a2​,b2​]×⋯×[ad​,bd​]
such that U⊂RU \subset RU⊂R.
• Assume f:U→Rf : U \to \mathbb{R}f:U→R is bounded on UUU; that is, there exists M>0M>0M>0 with ∣f(x)∣≤M\lvert f(x)\rvert \le M∣f(x)∣≤M for all x∈Ux\in Ux∈U.

Often, one extends fff by zero (or any convenient value) outside UUU so that it is defined on all of RRR, but equals the original fff on UUU. In that way, we only need partitions of RRR rather than partitions “just of UUU.”

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Partitions into Boxes
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A finite partition PPP of the bounding box RRR is given by choosing finitely many subdivision points in each coordinate direction. Concretely, one picks
ai  =  xi,0<xi,1<⋯<xi,ni  =  bi(i=1,…,d),a_i \;=\; x_{i,0} < x_{i,1} < \cdots < x_{i,n_i} \;=\; b_i \quad (i=1,\dots, d),ai​=xi,0​<xi,1​<⋯<xi,ni​​=bi​(i=1,…,d),
and takes all products
Bj1,j2,…,jd  =  [x1,j1−1,x1,j1]×[x2,j2−1,x2,j2]×⋯×[xd,jd−1,xd,jd],B_{j_1,j_2,\ldots,j_d} \;=\; [x_{1,j_1-1},x_{1,j_1}] \times [x_{2,j_2-1},x_{2,j_2}] \times \cdots \times [x_{d,j_d-1},x_{d,j_d}],Bj1​,j2​,…,jd​​=[x1,j1​−1​,x1,j1​​]×[x2,j2​−1​,x2,j2​​]×⋯×[xd,jd​−1​,xd,jd​​],
where 1≤ji≤ni1 \le j_i \le n_i1≤ji​≤ni​. Each such set BBB is a ddd-dimensional “box.” The union of all these boxes covers RRR, so in particular covers U⊂RU\subset RU⊂R.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Extending the Darboux Integral to ℝᵈ
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

To define “upper” and “lower” sums in higher dimensions, we do essentially what we did in 1D, but on each box BBB:

  1. For each box BBB in the partition PPP, consider the portion of BBB that lies in UUU, namely B∩UB \cap UB∩U.

  2. Define
    MB  =  sup⁡x∈B∩Uf(x),mB  =  inf⁡x∈B∩Uf(x).M_B \;=\; \sup_{x \in B \cap U} f(x), \qquad m_B \;=\; \inf_{x \in B \cap U} f(x).MB​=x∈B∩Usup​f(x),mB​=x∈B∩Uinf​f(x).
    (If B∩UB \cap UB∩U is empty, one often takes MB=0M_B = 0MB​=0 and mB=0m_B = 0mB​=0 or simply omits that box from the sums.)

  3. Let vol(B)\mathrm{vol}(B)vol(B) be the ddd-dimensional volume of the box BBB. Then define the upper and lower Darboux sums:
    U(P,f)  =  ∑B∈PMB vol(B),L(P,f)  =  ∑B∈PmB vol(B).U(P,f) \;=\; \sum_{B \in P} M_B \,\mathrm{vol}(B), \quad L(P,f) \;=\; \sum_{B \in P} m_B \,\mathrm{vol}(B).U(P,f)=B∈P∑​MB​vol(B),L(P,f)=B∈P∑​mB​vol(B).

  4. As in the 1D case, the upper Darboux integral is
    ∫U‾f  =  inf⁡P U(P,f),\overline{\int_U} f \;=\; \inf_P\, U(P,f),∫U​​f=Pinf​U(P,f),
    and the lower Darboux integral is
    ∫U‾f  =  sup⁡P L(P,f),\underline{\int_U} f \;=\; \sup_P\, L(P,f),∫U​​f=Psup​L(P,f),
    with both infimum and supremum taken over all possible partitions of RRR.

  5. If these two quantities coincide, we say fff is Darboux integrable on UUU and define
    ∫Uf  =  ∫U‾f  =  ∫U‾f.\int_U f \;=\; \underline{\int_U} f \;=\; \overline{\int_U} f.∫U​f=∫U​​f=∫U​​f.

This generalizes the one‐dimensional idea (sums of “suprema × subinterval length” vs. “infima × subinterval length”) to sums of “suprema × box volume” vs. “infima × box volume.”

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Extending the Riemann Integral via Tagged Partitions
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Similarly, for the Riemann integral in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd, we define a “tagged partition” of RRR:

  1. First form a partition PPP of RRR into finitely many boxes B1,B2,…,BNB_1,B_2,\dots,B_NB1​,B2​,…,BN​.

  2. In each box BjB_jBj​, choose a “tag” (a sample point) τj∈Bj∩U\tau_j \in B_j \cap Uτj​∈Bj​∩U.

  3. The Riemann sum of fff relative to (P,T)(P,T)(P,T) is
    Sf((P,T))  =  ∑j=1Nf(τj) vol(Bj).S_f\bigl((P,T)\bigr) \;=\; \sum_{j=1}^N f(\tau_j)\,\mathrm{vol}(B_j).Sf​((P,T))=j=1∑N​f(τj​)vol(Bj​).
    If Bj∩U=∅B_j \cap U = \emptysetBj​∩U=∅, one sets that term to 0 or omits it.

  4. The mesh (norm) of PPP is the maximum of the side‐lengths of the boxes in PPP. Taking finer and finer partitions shrinks this maximum side‐length to 0.

We say fff is (Riemann) integrable on U⊂RdU\subset \mathbb{R}^dU⊂Rd if there is a real number LLL such that for every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, one can make the mesh of the partition small enough so that all corresponding Riemann sums stay within ε\varepsilonε of LLL. Symbolically:
∀ε>0,  ∃δ>0:∥P∥<δ  ⟹  ∣ Sf((P,T))−L∣<ε.\forall \varepsilon>0,\;\exists\delta>0: \quad \|P\|<\delta \;\Longrightarrow\; \bigl|\,S_f((P,T)) - L\bigr| < \varepsilon.∀ε>0,∃δ>0:∥P∥<δ⟹​Sf​((P,T))−L​<ε.

If this limit LLL exists (independent of the choices of the tags τj\tau_jτj​), then we define
∫Uf  =  L.\int_U f \;=\; L.∫U​f=L.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Equivalence of the Two Definitions
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

In one dimension, we know that the Darboux and Riemann definitions coincide. The same holds in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd: a bounded function fff on a bounded region U⊂RdU\subset \mathbb{R}^dU⊂Rd is Darboux integrable if and only if it is Riemann integrable, and in that case the two integrals agree.

One often refers to both as the “Riemann–Darboux integral.”

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. To extend 1D Darboux integrals, we cover U⊂RdU\subset \mathbb{R}^dU⊂Rd with a grid of small boxes, take infimums and supremums of fff on each box (restricted to UUU), form lower and upper sums, then let the partition get arbitrarily fine.
  2. To extend 1D Riemann integrals, we do exactly what we did in one dimension but in multi‐dimensional boxes: pick a sample (“tag”) in each box to evaluate fff, multiply by the box’s volume, and sum. Refining partitions and requiring the sums to converge yields the Riemann integral.
  3. Both methods agree, provided fff is integrable in the sense that the upper and lower sums converge to the same limit (Darboux) or that all Riemann sums converge to the same value (Riemann).

Hence, the key 1D ideas—partitioning the domain, taking sup/inf or sample‐point evaluations, and letting the partition mesh go to zero—carry over verbatim, just using boxes and volume in place of intervals and length.

Lebesgue Outer measure

The Jordan outer measure which we shall now show as μ∗J\mu^{*J}μ∗J to distinguish from the Lebesgue outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ from hereon. For a set E⊂RdE \subset R^dE⊂Rd,
μ∗J=inf⁡E⊃B,B  elementaryμJ(B)\mu^{*J} = \inf_{E \supset B, B \; \text{elementary}} \mu^J(B)μ∗J=E⊃B,Belementaryinf​μJ(B)

Equivalently, we can replace the elementary BBB above with a finite union of boxes B1∪⋯BnB_1 \cup \cdots B_nB1​∪⋯Bn​. The infimum over the finite partition of boxes of ∑ivol(Bi)\sum_i \text{vol}(B_i)∑i​vol(Bi​).

By replacing the finite cover of boxes to a countably infinite cover of boxes, we pass from the Jordan outer measure to the Lebesgue outer measure.

Is this correct?

Below is a brief clarification of how the transition from “finite coverings by boxes” to “countably infinite coverings by boxes” leads from Jordan’s notion of outer measure to the Lebesgue outer measure:

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Jordan Outer Measure (Finite Covers)
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• For a bounded set E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd, the Jordan outer measure μ∗J(E)\mu^{*J}(E)μ∗J(E) is defined by
μ∗J(E)  =  inf⁡{μJ(B) ∣ B⊃E, B is an elementary set (finite union of boxes)}.\mu^{*J}(E) \;=\; \inf\Bigl\{ \mu^J(B) \,\Big|\, B \supset E, \,B \text{ is an elementary set (finite union of boxes)} \Bigr\}.μ∗J(E)=inf{μJ(B)​B⊃E,B is an elementary set (finite union of boxes)}.
In practice, we usually take B=B1∪⋯∪BnB = B_1 \cup \cdots \cup B_nB=B1​∪⋯∪Bn​, a finite union of boxes whose (Jordan) volume is
μJ(B)=∑i=1nvol(Bi).\mu^J(B) = \sum_{i=1}^n \mathrm{vol}(B_i).μJ(B)=∑i=1n​vol(Bi​).

• Thus, to find μ∗J(E)\mu^{*J}(E)μ∗J(E), we look at all possible finite covers of EEE by boxes B1,…,BnB_1,\dots,B_nB1​,…,Bn​ and take the infimum of the sum of their volumes.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Lebesgue Outer Measure (Countable Covers)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• The Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) allows covering EEE by \emph{countably many} boxes:
μ∗(E)  =  inf⁡{∑i=1∞vol(Ii) ∣ E⊂⋃i=1∞Ii, Ii are boxes}.\mu^*(E) \;=\; \inf\Bigl\{ \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(I_i) \,\Big|\, E\subset \bigcup_{i=1}^\infty I_i, \ I_i \text{ are boxes} \Bigr\}.μ∗(E)=inf{i=1∑∞​vol(Ii​)​E⊂i=1⋃∞​Ii​, Ii​ are boxes}.
• Comparing the two:
– Jordan outer measure restricts to finite\emph{finite}finite covers by boxes.
– Lebesgue outer measure allows countable\emph{countable}countable covers by boxes, hence is generally “less restrictive” (which in turn can yield a smaller infimum—i.e.\ μ∗(E)≤μ∗J(E)\mu^*(E)\le\mu^{*J}(E)μ∗(E)≤μ∗J(E) in most situations).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Is the Statement “By Replacing Finite Covers by Countably Many Covers
We Pass from Jordan to Lebesgue Outer Measure” Correct?
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Yes. In essence, the definition of Jordan outer measure is exactly like that of the Lebesgue outer measure except it limits itself to finite\emph{finite}finite families of boxes. The Lebesgue outer measure extends this by allowing countably infinite\emph{countably infinite}countably infinite families of boxes. Concretely:

• Jordan outer measure:
μ∗J(E)  =  inf⁡E⊂⋃i=1nBin<∞ ∑i=1nvol(Bi).\mu^{*J}(E) \;=\; \inf_{\substack{E \subset \bigcup_{i=1}^n B_i \\ n<\infty}} \, \sum_{i=1}^n \mathrm{vol}(B_i).μ∗J(E)=E⊂⋃i=1n​Bi​n<∞​inf​i=1∑n​vol(Bi​).
• Lebesgue outer measure:
μ∗(E)  =  inf⁡E⊂⋃i=1∞Bicountable ∑i=1∞vol(Bi).\mu^*(E) \;=\; \inf_{\substack{E \subset \bigcup_{i=1}^\infty B_i \\ \text{countable}}} \, \sum_{i=1}^\infty \mathrm{vol}(B_i).μ∗(E)=E⊂⋃i=1∞​Bi​countable​inf​i=1∑∞​vol(Bi​).

Thus, allowing infinite covers strictly generalizes the finite‐cover definition, moving from μ∗J\mu^{*J}μ∗J to μ∗\mu^*μ∗. Indeed, any set that can be covered by a finite collection can also be covered by the same set written as a countably infinite collection (just pad with empty sets), so
μ∗(E)  ≤  μ∗J(E).\mu^*(E) \;\le\; \mu^{*J}(E).μ∗(E)≤μ∗J(E).
Hence the statement that “by passing from finite to countably infinite covers, we move from Jordan outer measure to Lebesgue outer measure” is precisely correct.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Additional Note: Existence vs. Finiteness of the Jordan Measure
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Jordan measure (as opposed to Jordan outer\emph{outer}outer measure) is only defined for a restricted class of sets (“Jordan measurable” sets), basically those whose boundaries have measure zero and are bounded.
• Lebesgue measure, on the other hand, is well‐defined (possibly infinite) for \emph{every} subset of Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

Thus, the finite‐cover versus countably‐cover dichotomy reflects the broader fact that Lebesgue theory is strictly more general than Jordan’s, while coinciding for sets that are nicely “Jordan measurable.”

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Yes, the succinct statement is correct:
“By replacing finite box‐covers with countably infinite box‐covers in the definition, one passes from the Jordan outer measure μ∗J\mu^{*J}μ∗J to the Lebesgue outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗.”

Compare Jordan and Lebesgue outer measures on countable sets

Let E={x1,x2,⋯ }∈RdE = \{x_1, x_2, \cdots \} \in R^dE={x1​,x2​,⋯}∈Rd be a countable set. The Jordan outer measure μ∗(J)(E)\mu^{* (J)}(E)μ∗(J)(E) can be large and in some cases infinite while the Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) is zero. Prove this.

Explanation in steps:

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Setup and Notation
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let E={x1,x2,… }⊂RdE = \{x_1, x_2, \dots\}\subset \mathbb{R}^dE={x1​,x2​,…}⊂Rd be a countably infinite set. We compare:

• The Jordan outer measure μ∗(J)(E)\mu^{*(J)}(E)μ∗(J)(E), which uses only finite covers by boxes.
• The Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E), which uses countable covers by boxes.

Recall:

  1. Jordan outer measure:
    μ∗(J)(E)  =  inf⁡{∑i=1nvol(Bi)  ∣  E  ⊂  ⋃i=1nBi, Bi are (closed/open) boxes, n<∞}.\mu^{*(J)}(E) \;=\; \inf\Bigl\{ \sum_{i=1}^n \mathrm{vol}(B_i) \;\Big|\; E\;\subset\; \bigcup_{i=1}^n B_i,\, B_i \text{ are (closed/open) boxes},\,n<\infty \Bigr\}.μ∗(J)(E)=inf{i=1∑n​vol(Bi​)​E⊂i=1⋃n​Bi​,Bi​ are (closed/open) boxes,n<∞}.

  2. Lebesgue outer measure:
    μ∗(E)  =  inf⁡{∑i=1∞vol(Bi)  ∣  E  ⊂  ⋃i=1∞Bi, Bi are boxes}.\mu^*(E) \;=\; \inf\Bigl\{ \sum_{i=1}^\infty \mathrm{vol}(B_i) \;\Big|\; E\;\subset\; \bigcup_{i=1}^\infty B_i,\, B_i \text{ are boxes} \Bigr\}.μ∗(E)=inf{i=1∑∞​vol(Bi​)​E⊂i=1⋃∞​Bi​,Bi​ are boxes}.

Below we prove two statements:

(1) μ∗(E)=0\mu^*(E)=0μ∗(E)=0 for every countable set EEE.
(2) μ∗(J)(E)\mu^{*(J)}(E)μ∗(J)(E) can be arbitrarily large (or even infinite), depending on how EEE is “spread out,” in particular if EEE has limit points or is dense in some region.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Proof That Lebesgue Outer Measure of a Countable Set Is Zero
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

To show μ∗(E)=0\mu^*(E)=0μ∗(E)=0 for any countable E⊂RdE\subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd:

• Enumerate the points of EEE as x1,x2,…x_1, x_2,\dotsx1​,x2​,….
• For each i=1,2,…i=1,2,\dotsi=1,2,…, choose a little box BiB_iBi​ around xix_ixi​ of volume at most ε2i\tfrac{\varepsilon}{2^i}2iε​.

Then E⊂⋃i=1∞BiE\subset \bigcup_{i=1}^\infty B_iE⊂⋃i=1∞​Bi​ and the total volume is
∑i=1∞vol(Bi)  ≤  ∑i=1∞ε2i  =  ε.\sum_{i=1}^\infty \mathrm{vol}(B_i) \;\le\; \sum_{i=1}^\infty \frac{\varepsilon}{2^i} \;=\; \varepsilon.i=1∑∞​vol(Bi​)≤i=1∑∞​2iε​=ε.
Since ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0 was arbitrary, the infimum of such sums is 000. Thus
μ∗(E)  =  0.\mu^*(E) \;=\; 0.μ∗(E)=0.

In other words, any countable set has Lebesgue outer measure 000.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Example Where the Jordan Outer Measure Is “Large” or Infinite
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

While the Lebesgue outer measure of a countable set in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd is always zero, the Jordan outer measure can fail to be small (or even finite) if one insists on \emph{finite covers}. A standard illustration is:

• Let E=[0,1]∩QE=[0,1]\cap \mathbb{Q}E=[0,1]∩Q be the set of rational points in the unit interval in R\mathbb{R}R.
• It is a countable set, so μ∗(E)=0\mu^*(E)=0μ∗(E)=0.

However, to cover \emph{all} rational points in [0,1][0,1][0,1] with a \emph{finite} union of intervals, one is effectively forced to cover \emph{every} subinterval of [0,1][0,1][0,1]. Indeed, if you leave out any subinterval, that subinterval contains a rational point not covered—a contradiction. Thus, the only successful finite cover of all rationals in [0,1][0,1][0,1] necessarily covers [0,1][0,1][0,1] entirely, giving:

μ∗(J)(E)  =  μ∗(J)([0,1]∩Q)  =  vol([0,1])  =  1.\mu^{*(J)}(E) \;=\; \mu^{*(J)}\bigl([0,1]\cap\mathbb{Q}\bigr) \;=\; \mathrm{vol}\bigl([0,1]\bigr) \;=\; 1.μ∗(J)(E)=μ∗(J)([0,1]∩Q)=vol([0,1])=1.
Hence, for this countable set μ∗(J)(E)=1\mu^{*(J)}(E)=1μ∗(J)(E)=1, contrasting with μ∗(E)=0\mu^*(E)=0μ∗(E)=0.

More generally, any countable set EEE that is dense in some region Ω⊂Rd\Omega\subset \mathbb{R}^dΩ⊂Rd forces any finite family of boxes covering EEE to cover all of Ω\OmegaΩ. Because vol(Ω)\mathrm{vol}(\Omega)vol(Ω) might be positive (or unbounded), μ∗(J)(E)\mu^{*(J)}(E)μ∗(J)(E) can be as large as vol(Ω)\mathrm{vol}(\Omega)vol(Ω) or even infinite.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Summary
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. For any countable E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd, its Lebesgue outer measure is always zero: μ∗(E)=0\mu^*(E)=0μ∗(E)=0.
  2. The Jordan outer measure μ∗(J)(E)\mu^{*(J)}(E)μ∗(J)(E), which only allows \emph{finite} covers by boxes, can be positive or even infinite for some countable sets (e.g.\ dense sets within a region).
    – A classic example: the rationals in [0,1][0,1][0,1]. They have μ∗(Q∩[0,1])=0\mu^*\bigl(\mathbb{Q}\cap[0,1]\bigr)=0μ∗(Q∩[0,1])=0 but μ∗(J)(Q∩[0,1])=1\mu^{*(J)}\bigl(\mathbb{Q}\cap[0,1]\bigr)=1μ∗(J)(Q∩[0,1])=1.

This illustrates the fundamental difference between these two outer measures and why the Jordan measure, in general, applies only to “nice” (Jordan measurable) sets, whereas Lebesgue measure extends to all sets in a more refined manner.

Lebesgue measurability

Let E⊂RdE \subset R^dE⊂Rd. Let μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) be the outer measure of EEE. Let U⊂RdU \subset R^dU⊂Rd be an open set such that for any ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there is an open set U⊂RdU \subset R^dU⊂Rd such that μ∗(U∖E)≤ε\mu^*(U \setminus E) \leq \varepsilonμ∗(U∖E)≤ε. Then EEE is said to be Lebesgue measurable.

This can be used as a definition of Lebesgue measurability. This construction avoids using the Caratheodory criterion. What do you think?

First, let us restate the proposed definition in a more standard way:

Definition (Via Approximation by Open Sets).
A set E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd is called Lebesgue measurable if, for every ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there exists an open set U⊂RdU \subset \mathbb{R}^dU⊂Rd such that
E  ⊂  Uandμ∗(U∖E)  ≤  ε,E \;\subset\; U \quad\text{and}\quad \mu^*\bigl(U \setminus E\bigr) \;\le\; \varepsilon,E⊂Uandμ∗(U∖E)≤ε,
where μ∗(⋅)\mu^*(\cdot)μ∗(⋅) denotes the Lebesgue outer measure.

Below is a step-by-step outline explaining why this indeed provides a valid definition of Lebesgue measurability, and how it relates to the usual Carathéodory criterion.

  1. Carathéodory's Criterion (Classical Definition)

Usually, one introduces the outer measure μ∗(⋅)\mu^*(\cdot)μ∗(⋅) on all subsets of Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd via coverings by countable collections of boxes (or open sets). Then, one defines:

Carathéodory's Criterion.
A set E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd is Lebesgue measurable if and only if, for every set A⊂RdA \subset \mathbb{R}^dA⊂Rd,
μ∗(A)  =  μ∗(A∩E)  +  μ∗(A∩Ec).\mu^*(A) \;=\; \mu^*\bigl(A \cap E\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(A \cap E^c\bigr).μ∗(A)=μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec).

It can be shown that sets satisfying this criterion form a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, and the restriction of μ∗\mu^*μ∗ to these sets is indeed the Lebesgue measure.

  1. Equivalence with Approximation by Open Sets

An equivalent way to say that EEE is Lebesgue measurable is:

  • For every ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, one can find an open set U⊃EU \supset EU⊃E whose “difference” from EEE has arbitrarily small outer measure, i.e.,
    μ∗(U∖E)  ≤  ε.\mu^*\bigl(U \setminus E\bigr) \;\le\; \varepsilon.μ∗(U∖E)≤ε.

Intuitively, this means EEE can be “expanded” slightly to an open set UUU without changing its outer measure by more than ε\varepsilonε. One then shows that this is equivalent to Carathéodory’s condition. The main steps are:

(a) If EEE satisfies Carathéodory’s criterion, one uses the regularity property of Lebesgue measure (or outer measure) to approximate EEE from above by open sets of outer measure arbitrarily close to μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E). One obtains
μ∗(U∖E) = μ∗(U) − μ∗(U∩Ec) ≈ μ∗(E) − μ∗(E) = 0,\mu^*\bigl(U \setminus E\bigr) \,=\, \mu^*(U) \,-\, \mu^*\bigl(U \cap E^c\bigr) \,\approx\, \mu^*(E) \,-\, \mu^*(E) \,=\, 0,μ∗(U∖E)=μ∗(U)−μ∗(U∩Ec)≈μ∗(E)−μ∗(E)=0,
for a suitably chosen U⊃EU\supset EU⊃E. By carefully optimizing these choices, one forces μ∗((U∖E)\mu^*((U\setminus E)μ∗((U∖E) to be less than ε\varepsilonε.

(b) Conversely, if for every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0 you can cover EEE by an open set UUU with μ∗(U∖E)≤ε\mu^*(U\setminus E)\le\varepsilonμ∗(U∖E)≤ε, then one shows by a set-containment argument (plus subadditivity and other properties of μ∗\mu^*μ∗) that Carathéodory’s splitting condition
μ∗(A) = μ∗(A∩E)  +  μ∗(A∩Ec)\mu^*(A) \,=\, \mu^*\bigl(A \cap E\bigr) \;+\; \mu^*\bigl(A \cap E^c\bigr)μ∗(A)=μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)
also holds. Essentially, given a set AAA, one approximates A∩EA\cap EA∩E by (A∩U)(A\cap U)(A∩U) and notes that the difference in measure can be chosen to be arbitrarily small.

Thus, the approximation-by-open-sets condition and the Carathéodory criterion are logically equivalent.

  1. Practical and Conceptual Advantages

Using “approximation by open sets” (together with “approximation by closed sets” from below if needed) is particularly natural once one knows:
