• The regularity of Lebesgue measure: every Lebesgue measurable set can be approximated from above by open sets and from below by closed sets in terms of measure.

• The Borel σ\sigmaσ-algebra and its completion: one can first define Lebesgue measure on all Borel sets (as an extension of the usual notion of volume) and then extend to all subsets of measure-zero modifications of Borel sets. In this viewpoint, saying “EEE is contained in an open set UUU with U∖EU\setminus EU∖E small in outer measure” is a natural statement about how close EEE is to a Borel set (indeed UUU is Borel).

Hence, many texts prefer Carathéodory’s definition as the starting axiom for measure extension, while others introduce Lebesgue measure on the Borel sets first and then define a set to be (Lebesgue) measurable if it differs from a Borel set by a set of measure zero. One then proves that these extended measurable sets are exactly those that can be approximated from above by open sets in outer measure.

  1. Conclusion

Yes, one can take “for every ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, there is an open set U⊃EU\supset EU⊃E with μ∗(U∖E)≤ε\mu^*(U\setminus E)\le \varepsilonμ∗(U∖E)≤ε” as a perfectly valid definition of Lebesgue measurability. It is indeed equivalent to the usual Carathéodory criterion:

• The approximation-by-open-sets property ↔ Carathéodory’s splitting condition.

This definition avoids directly invoking Carathéodory’s criterion, but in the background, a similar argument is used to show equivalence (by leveraging outer measure properties, subadditivity, and the structure of open/closed sets). Hence, from a purely logical standpoint, it is a sound and commonly known alternative approach to defining Lebesgue measurability.

Properties of Lebesgue Outer measure

What are the properties of the Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(⋅)\mu^*(\cdot)μ∗(⋅) which is defined using the construction of the infimum of sum of the volumes of a countable cover of boxes?

Below is a step-by-step overview of the fundamental properties of the Lebesgue outer measure, denoted by μ∗(⋅)\mu^*(\cdot)μ∗(⋅), which is defined by covering a set with countably many boxes (or intervals/rectangles in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd) and taking the infimum of the total volumes of those boxes.

  1. Construction of the Lebesgue Outer Measure

Let E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd. We define
μ∗(E)  =  inf⁡{∑k=1∞ℓ(Ik): E ⊂ ⋃k=1∞Ik, where each Ik is a (closed or open) box in Rd},\mu^*(E) \;=\; \inf \left\{ \sum_{k=1}^\infty \ell\bigl(I_k\bigr) :\, E \,\subset\, \bigcup_{k=1}^\infty I_k, \ \text{where each } I_k \text{ is a (closed or open) box in } \mathbb{R}^d \right\},μ∗(E)=inf{k=1∑∞​ℓ(Ik​):E⊂k=1⋃∞​Ik​, where each Ik​ is a (closed or open) box in Rd},
where ℓ(Ik)\ell(I_k)ℓ(Ik​) denotes the usual ddd-dimensional volume (length, area, etc.) of the box IkI_kIk​.

  1. Monotonicity

The outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is monotonically increasing, meaning:

A ⊂ B⟹μ∗(A)  ≤  μ∗(B).A \,\subset\, B \quad\Longrightarrow\quad \mu^*(A) \;\le\; \mu^*(B).A⊂B⟹μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B).

Reasoning:
• If A⊂BA \subset BA⊂B, then any countable collection of boxes covering BBB also covers AAA.
• Therefore, the infimum of sums of volumes needed to cover AAA cannot exceed that needed to cover BBB.

  1. Countable Subadditivity (or Subadditivity in General)

The outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is countably subadditive, meaning:

μ∗ ⁣(⋃k=1∞Ek)  ≤  ∑k=1∞μ∗(Ek).\mu^*\!\Bigl(\bigcup_{k=1}^\infty E_k\Bigr) \;\le\; \sum_{k=1}^\infty \mu^*(E_k).μ∗(k=1⋃∞​Ek​)≤k=1∑∞​μ∗(Ek​).

Reasoning:
• Given countably many sets EkE_kEk​, for each kkk choose a cover by boxes {Ik,j}j=1∞\{I_{k,j}\}_{j=1}^\infty{Ik,j​}j=1∞​ such that
Ek ⊂ ⋃j=1∞Ik,jand∑j=1∞ℓ(Ik,j)  <  μ∗(Ek)+ε2k,E_k \,\subset\, \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty I_{k,j} \quad\text{and}\quad \sum_{j=1}^\infty \ell(I_{k,j}) \;<\; \mu^*(E_k) + \frac{\varepsilon}{2^k},Ek​⊂j=1⋃∞​Ik,j​andj=1∑∞​ℓ(Ik,j​)<μ∗(Ek​)+2kε​,
for some small ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0.
• Then
⋃k=1∞Ek  ⊂  ⋃k=1∞⋃j=1∞Ik,j,\bigcup_{k=1}^\infty E_k \;\subset\; \bigcup_{k=1}^\infty\bigcup_{j=1}^\infty I_{k,j},k=1⋃∞​Ek​⊂k=1⋃∞​j=1⋃∞​Ik,j​,
and the total volume of that cover is
∑k=1∞∑j=1∞ℓ(Ik,j)  ≤  ∑k=1∞(μ∗(Ek)+ε2k)  =  ε+∑k=1∞μ∗(Ek).\sum_{k=1}^\infty \sum_{j=1}^\infty \ell(I_{k,j}) \;\le\; \sum_{k=1}^\infty \Bigl( \mu^*(E_k) + \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2^k} \Bigr) \;=\; \varepsilon + \sum_{k=1}^\infty \mu^*(E_k).k=1∑∞​j=1∑∞​ℓ(Ik,j​)≤k=1∑∞​(μ∗(Ek​)+2kε​)=ε+k=1∑∞​μ∗(Ek​).
• Taking the infimum over all such choices and letting ε→0\varepsilon\to 0ε→0 implies the result.

  1. Translation Invariance

For any E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd and any x∈Rdx \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd, define
E+x  =  { y+x : y∈E}.E + x \;=\; \{\,y + x \,:\, y \in E \}.E+x={y+x:y∈E}.

Then,

μ∗(E+x)  =  μ∗(E).\mu^*(E + x) \;=\; \mu^*(E).μ∗(E+x)=μ∗(E).

Reasoning:
• Translating a cover of EEE by xxx gives a cover of E+xE + xE+x with the same total volume, and vice versa.
• Hence the infimum of volumes that cover EEE is the same as that for E+xE+xE+x.

  1. Consistency with Volume on Boxes

By definition, if III is a box in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd with sides of lengths a1,a2,…,ada_1, a_2, \dots, a_da1​,a2​,…,ad​, then

μ∗(I)  =  ℓ(I)  =  a1×a2×⋯×ad,\mu^*(I) \;=\; \ell(I) \;=\; a_1 \times a_2 \times \cdots \times a_d,μ∗(I)=ℓ(I)=a1​×a2​×⋯×ad​,

i.e., the outer measure agrees with the usual notion of the volume of a box.

  1. Non-Negativity and Null Set for the Empty Set

• Non-negativity:
μ∗(E)  ≥  0\displaystyle \mu^*(E) \;\ge\; 0μ∗(E)≥0 for all E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd.

• Measure of the empty set:
μ∗(∅)=0\displaystyle \mu^*(\varnothing) = 0μ∗(∅)=0.

These follow directly from the definition, as covering ∅\varnothing∅ requires no boxes.

  1. Additional Remarks on Completeness and Extension

• Once one identifies the collection of Lebesgue measurable sets via Carathéodory’s criterion (or the open-set-approximation criterion), one restricts μ∗\mu^*μ∗ to that σ\sigmaσ-algebra.
• This yields a complete measure space: any subset of a μ∗\mu^*μ∗-null set (i.e., a set of outer measure zero) is also measurable and has measure zero.

Summary of Key Properties

  1. Monotonicity: If A⊂BA \subset BA⊂B, then μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B)\mu^*(A) \le \mu^*(B)μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B).
  2. Countable Subadditivity: μ∗(⋃k=1∞Ek)≤∑k=1∞μ∗(Ek)\mu^*\bigl(\bigcup_{k=1}^\infty E_k\bigr) \le \sum_{k=1}^\infty \mu^*(E_k)μ∗(⋃k=1∞​Ek​)≤∑k=1∞​μ∗(Ek​).
  3. Translation Invariance: μ∗(E+x)=μ∗(E)\mu^*(E + x) = \mu^*(E)μ∗(E+x)=μ∗(E) for all x∈Rdx \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd.
  4. Agreement with Volume: For any box III, μ∗(I)\mu^*(I)μ∗(I) equals the usual volume of III.
  5. Non-negativity and μ∗(∅)=0\mu^*(\varnothing)=0μ∗(∅)=0.

These properties are the backbone for constructing and studying Lebesgue measure on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n trick

What is the ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n trick in the context of proving results regarding Lebesgue measures. It comes up when the set in question is covered by boxes in RdR^dRd

In proofs involving Lebesgue measure (or outer measure) in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd, one often wants to cover a given set EEE by a collection of boxes (rectangles) whose total volume can be made arbitrarily small (or arbitrarily close to some target number). The “ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n trick” (also sometimes called the “halving trick”) is a systematic way to achieve this in countably many steps, so that the total “error” or total “excess volume” remains below a chosen ε\varepsilonε. Below is an outline of how and why it works.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

  1. The usual difficulty and the core idea
    ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

● Difficulty:
Suppose you want a single cover of EEE by finitely or countably many boxes whose total volume is no more than (say) μ∗(E)+ε\mu^*(E) + \varepsilonμ∗(E)+ε. However, the process of covering EEE might naturally happen in multiple stages (e.g., successively covering “leftover” parts of EEE that were missed by earlier steps).

● Core Idea (“Halving” the ε\varepsilonε each time):
Rather than trying to ensure at each intermediate step that the error is smaller than the same ε\varepsilonε, we allow ourselves smaller and smaller fractions of ε\varepsilonε, specifically ε2,ε4,ε8,…\frac{\varepsilon}{2}, \frac{\varepsilon}{4}, \frac{\varepsilon}{8},\dots2ε​,4ε​,8ε​,…. In the end, the sum of all these fractions is still at most ε\varepsilonε.

Mathematically, if you do something “wrong” (or “use up some measure”) by at most ε2\frac{\varepsilon}{2}2ε​ at the first step, then at most ε4\frac{\varepsilon}{4}4ε​ at the second step, etc., the total over infinitely many steps is
ε2  +  ε4  +  ε8  +  …  =  ε.\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \;+\; \frac{\varepsilon}{4} \;+\; \frac{\varepsilon}{8} \;+\; \dots \;=\; \varepsilon.2ε​+4ε​+8ε​+…=ε.
Hence, you never exceed your overall error budget ε\varepsilonε.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
2) A common scenario in measure theory
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

A prototypical place the ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n trick appears is in showing that the Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) can be approximated arbitrarily closely by covers of EEE by boxes in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd. For instance:

◾ You know that
μ∗(E)  =  inf⁡{ ∑ivol(Ri)   ⁣:  E⊆⋃iRi, Ri are boxes}.\mu^*(E) \;=\; \inf\Bigl\{\,\sum_{i} \mathrm{vol}(R_i) \;\colon\; E\subseteq\bigcup_i R_i,\ R_i\text{ are boxes}\Bigr\}.μ∗(E)=inf{i∑​vol(Ri​):E⊆i⋃​Ri​, Ri​ are boxes}.

◾ You want to show there is, in fact, a single (finite or countable) cover by boxes whose total volume is <μ∗(E)+ε< \mu^*(E) + \varepsilon<μ∗(E)+ε.

Because the outer measure is defined via an infimum, you do not automatically have a single cover attains that infimum. Instead, you construct a sequence of near-optimal covers, each stage improving the total volume by at most ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n. Summing up all these small improvements gives you one final cover whose total volume is within ε\varepsilonε of the infimum.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
3) Typical step-by-step application
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Here is how one often applies the ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n strategy in detail:

  1. Start with your desired total “error budget” ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0.

  2. Because μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) is an infimum over covers, for the first stage (say n=1n=1n=1), you can find a countable (or finite) collection of boxes {Ri(1)}\{R_i^{(1)}\}{Ri(1)​} covering EEE such that
    ∑ivol(Ri(1))  ≤  μ∗(E)  +  ε2.\sum_i \mathrm{vol}\bigl(R_i^{(1)}\bigr) \;\le\; \mu^*(E)\;+\;\frac{\varepsilon}{2}.i∑​vol(Ri(1)​)≤μ∗(E)+2ε​.

  3. Now, maybe you still want to refine something about this cover further—e.g., remove redundant boxes, or handle boundary issues, or cover only leftover uncovered parts of EEE. You allow yourself an additional ε4\tfrac{\varepsilon}{4}4ε​ “volume budget” to fix those issues. Concretely, you produce a second collection of boxes {Ri(2)}\{R_i^{(2)}\}{Ri(2)​} such that
    ∑ivol(Ri(2))  ≤  [μ∗(E)+ε2]  +  ε4.\sum_i \mathrm{vol}\bigl(R_i^{(2)}\bigr) \;\le\; \bigl[\mu^*(E) + \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}\bigr]\;+\;\tfrac{\varepsilon}{4}.i∑​vol(Ri(2)​)≤[μ∗(E)+2ε​]+4ε​.

  4. If you repeat such a procedure at the nnn-th step, you might have a new cover {Ri(n)}\{R_i^{(n)}\}{Ri(n)​} whose total volume is
    ∑ivol(Ri(n))  ≤  μ∗(E)  +  ε2+ε4+⋯+ε2n.\sum_i \mathrm{vol}\bigl(R_i^{(n)}\bigr) \;\le\; \mu^*(E) \;+\; \frac{\varepsilon}{2} + \frac{\varepsilon}{4} + \cdots + \frac{\varepsilon}{2^n}.i∑​vol(Ri(n)​)≤μ∗(E)+2ε​+4ε​+⋯+2nε​.

  5. Since
    ε2  +  ε4  +  ⋯  +  ε2n  =  ε(1−12n)  →  εas n→∞,\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \;+\; \frac{\varepsilon}{4} \;+\;\cdots \;+\;\frac{\varepsilon}{2^n} \;=\; \varepsilon\Bigl(1-\frac{1}{2^n}\Bigr) \;\to\; \varepsilon \quad \text{as }n\to\infty,2ε​+4ε​+⋯+2nε​=ε(1−2n1​)→εas n→∞,
    in the limit, you end up with a cover with total volume at most μ∗(E)+ε\mu^*(E) + \varepsilonμ∗(E)+ε.

  6. You can then combine all those boxes from your final stage (or union them if needed), so that the total volume is still within ε\varepsilonε of the infimum μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E).

Thus, the “ε\varepsilonε-error” is “spread across” infinitely many small improvements, each of size ε2n\frac{\varepsilon}{2^n}2nε​. The sum of those infinitely many small pieces is bounded by ε\varepsilonε.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
4) Why it is so ubiquitous
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

• Countable additivity / subadditivity in measure theory:
Because measure is countably subadditive, having a “small error” on infinitely many steps doesn’t necessarily blow up the total error. The geometric series ∑ε2n\sum \frac{\varepsilon}{2^n}∑2nε​ remains finite.

• Flexible approximations:
Many standard proofs (e.g., constructing outer approximations, Fubini–Tonelli arguments, or showing that open sets are unions of cubes with arbitrarily small leftover measure, etc.) proceed by gradually refining covers or partitions. At each refinement step, the overhead volume can be forced below ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n.

• Ensuring a single final cover (rather than infinitely many partial covers):
After each step, you keep the boxes you want, discard or adjust the ones you do not, and accept only an extra ε2n\frac{\varepsilon}{2^n}2nε​ of volume “waste.” In the end, you collect all the final boxes into one big cover. The total measure overhead from all steps is bounded by ε\varepsilonε.

In short, the ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n trick is a staple in measure theory because it handles the infinite process of refining covers in such a way that the total volume overhead is controlled by a convergent geometric series.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
5) Summary
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

The “ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n trick” is simply the systematic practice of splitting your allowable error ε\varepsilonε into a geometric sequence of smaller portions—ε2,ε4,ε8,…\tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}, \tfrac{\varepsilon}{4}, \tfrac{\varepsilon}{8},\dots2ε​,4ε​,8ε​,…. When covering a set EEE by a sequence of (hopefully better and better) covers, each refinement can “use up” only ε2n\tfrac{\varepsilon}{2^n}2nε​ of extra volume. Summing these yields a total error below ε\varepsilonε. Thus, by the final stage (or a union of all stages), you obtain a single cover whose volume is within ε\varepsilonε of the optimal possible measure. This elegantly resolves infinite-step constructions in measure theory while keeping track of the total cost in a finite way.

The Lebesgue outer measure of an elementary set

Let E⊂ofRdE \subset of R^dE⊂ofRd be a bounded, elementary set. An elementary set is one which is a finite or countably finite union of "boxes" in RdR^dRd. We can define the elementary measure μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E), the Jordan outer measure μ∗,(J)\mu^{*,(J)}μ∗,(J) and the Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) in the standard manner. We note that in this case, μ(E)=μ∗,(J)\mu(E) = \mu^{*,(J)}μ(E)=μ∗,(J).

We need to prove that μ∗(E)=μ(E)\mu^* (E) = \mu(E)μ∗(E)=μ(E).

First we note that We have to prove two inequalities:
μ∗(E)≤μ(E)μ(E)≤μ∗(E)\mu^* (E) \leq \mu(E) \qquad \mu(E) \leq \mu^* (E)μ∗(E)≤μ(E)μ(E)≤μ∗(E)

The first inequality follows easily since the Lebesgue outer measure follows from a countable cover of boxes while the Jordan outer measure is from a finite cover. With the freedom afforded by the countable cover, the inequality follows.

To prove the second inequality, we will use the Heine Borel theorem - for a bounded set such as EEE, every open cover will have a finite subcover. The boxes we choose to cover EEE can be made open using the ε/2n\varepsilon/2^nε/2n trick. The volume of the subcover on which μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E) is based will be ≤\leq≤ the volume of the conuntable cover of EEE on which μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) is based.

Fill in details to make this proof rigorous.

Below is a step‐by‐step proof that, for a bounded elementary set E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd, its Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) equals its elementary (or Jordan) measure μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E). The argument hinges on two inequalities:
μ∗(E)  ≤  μ(E)andμ(E)  ≤  μ∗(E).\mu^* (E) \;\le\; \mu(E) \quad\text{and}\quad \mu(E) \;\le\; \mu^* (E).μ∗(E)≤μ(E)andμ(E)≤μ∗(E).
We prove each in turn.

  1. Proof that μ∗(E)≤μ(E)\mu^*(E) \leq \mu(E)μ∗(E)≤μ(E)

By definition,

  • μ∗(E)=inf⁡{∑k=1∞vol(Bk)  ∣  E⊂⋃k=1∞Bk, Bk are boxes}\displaystyle \mu^*(E) = \inf \Big\{ \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(B_k) \;\Big|\; E \subset \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} B_k,\, B_k\text{ are boxes} \Big\}μ∗(E)=inf{k=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)​E⊂k=1⋃∞​Bk​,Bk​ are boxes}.

  • μ(E)=inf⁡{∑j=1nvol(Cj)  ∣  E⊂⋃j=1nCj, Cj are boxes (finite cover)}.\displaystyle \mu(E) = \inf \Big\{ \sum_{j=1}^n \mathrm{vol}(C_j) \;\Big|\; E \subset \bigcup_{j=1}^n C_j,\, C_j\text{ are boxes (finite cover)} \Big\}.μ(E)=inf{j=1∑n​vol(Cj​)​E⊂j=1⋃n​Cj​,Cj​ are boxes (finite cover)}.

Because μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E) is defined via finite covers and μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) via countable covers, each finite cover of EEE by boxes is, in particular, also a countable cover (just add infinitely many empty boxes if one wishes). Hence any candidate sum of volumes that appears in the definition of μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E) is also a candidate for μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E). Taking the infimum over all finite covers in μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E) and the infimum over all countable covers in μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E) yields:
μ∗(E)  ≤  μ(E).\mu^* (E)\;\le\;\mu(E).μ∗(E)≤μ(E).

  1. Proof that μ(E)≤μ∗(E)\mu(E) \leq \mu^*(E)μ(E)≤μ∗(E)

For each ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, let
∑k=1∞vol(Bk)  <  μ∗(E)+ε\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(B_k) \;<\; \mu^*(E) + \varepsilonk=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)<μ∗(E)+ε
be a covering of EEE by countably many boxes {Bk}k=1∞\{B_k\}_{k=1}^\infty{Bk​}k=1∞​. Thus
E  ⊂  ⋃k=1∞Bk.E \;\subset\; \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} B_k.E⊂k=1⋃∞​Bk​.

Since EEE is given to be bounded, we can use the Heine–Borel Theorem, which states that every open cover of a bounded (and closed) set in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd has a finite subcover. To apply it rigorously here, one often inflates each box BkB_kBk​ slightly to ensure they are open sets (for instance, replace each closed interval factor [a,b][a,b][a,b] in a box by an open interval (a−δ,b+δ)(a-\delta,b+\delta)(a−δ,b+δ), adjusting δ\deltaδ to be arbitrarily small). In any case, we obtain an open cover of EEE. By Heine–Borel, there exists a finite subcollection {Bk1,Bk2,…,Bkm}\{B_{k_1}, B_{k_2}, \ldots, B_{k_m}\}{Bk1​​,Bk2​​,…,Bkm​​} such that
E  ⊂  ⋃ℓ=1mBkℓ.E \;\subset\; \bigcup_{\ell=1}^m B_{k_\ell}.E⊂ℓ=1⋃m​Bkℓ​​.

Now, observe that the volume of the finite subcover cannot exceed the total volume of the original countable cover. Hence
∑ℓ=1mvol(Bkℓ)  ≤  ∑k=1∞vol(Bk)  <  μ∗(E)+ε.\sum_{\ell=1}^m \mathrm{vol}\bigl(B_{k_\ell}\bigr) \;\le\; \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(B_k) \;<\; \mu^*(E) + \varepsilon.ℓ=1∑m​vol(Bkℓ​​)≤k=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)<μ∗(E)+ε.
Since E⊂⋃ℓ=1mBkℓE\subset \bigcup_{\ell=1}^m B_{k_\ell}E⊂⋃ℓ=1m​Bkℓ​​ is a finite cover of EEE, by the very definition of the elementary (Jordan) measure, we have
μ(E)  ≤  ∑ℓ=1mvol(Bkℓ)  ≤  μ∗(E)+ε.\mu(E) \;\le\; \sum_{\ell=1}^m \mathrm{vol}\bigl(B_{k_\ell}\bigr) \;\le\; \mu^*(E) + \varepsilon.μ(E)≤ℓ=1∑m​vol(Bkℓ​​)≤μ∗(E)+ε.
Because ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0 was arbitrary, letting ε→0\varepsilon \to 0ε→0 yields
μ(E)  ≤  μ∗(E).\mu(E) \;\le\; \mu^*(E).μ(E)≤μ∗(E).

Conclusion

Combining both inequalities,
μ∗(E)  ≤  μ(E)andμ(E)  ≤  μ∗(E),\mu^*(E) \;\le\; \mu(E) \quad\text{and}\quad \mu(E) \;\le\; \mu^*(E),μ∗(E)≤μ(E)andμ(E)≤μ∗(E),
we conclude that
μ∗(E)  =  μ(E).\mu^*(E) \;=\; \mu(E).μ∗(E)=μ(E).
Thus, for a bounded elementary set E⊂RdE\subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd, its Lebesgue outer measure and its elementary (Jordan) measure coincide.

Making the boxes open

Below is a more detailed explanation of how to inflate each box in a controlled way so that we still stay within a volume bound of μ∗(E)+ε\mu^*(E) + \varepsilonμ∗(E)+ε. This clarification fills in the gap needed prior to applying Heine–Borel in the proof.

  1. Setup: A countable cover by boxes

Fix ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. By the definition of the Lebesgue outer measure μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E), there is a countable collection of boxes {Bk}k=1∞\{B_k\}_{k=1}^{\infty}{Bk​}k=1∞​ such that
E  ⊂  ⋃k=1∞Bkand∑k=1∞vol(Bk)  <  μ∗(E)  +  ε2.E \;\subset\; \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} B_k \quad\text{and}\quad \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol} \bigl(B_k\bigr) \;<\;\mu^*(E)\;+\;\frac{\varepsilon}{2}.E⊂k=1⋃∞​Bk​andk=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)<μ∗(E)+2ε​.

We wish to modify each BkB_kBk​ slightly into an open box B~k\widetilde{B}_kBk​ so that ∑k=1∞vol(B~k)\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(\widetilde{B}_k)∑k=1∞​vol(Bk​) remains bounded by μ∗(E)+ε\mu^*(E) + \varepsilonμ∗(E)+ε.

  1. Inflating each box in a controlled manner

Each BkB_kBk​ is typically a product of intervals. For simplicity, assume
Bk  =  [ak,1, bk,1] ×⋯×[ak,d, bk,d]  ⊂  Rd.B_k \;=\; [a_{k,1},\,b_{k,1}]\,\times \cdots \times [a_{k,d},\,b_{k,d}] \;\subset\; \mathbb{R}^d.Bk​=[ak,1​,bk,1​]×⋯×[ak,d​,bk,d​]⊂Rd.
We now choose δk>0\delta_k > 0δk​>0 sufficiently small so that the open box
B~k  =  (ak,1−δk,  bk,1+δk) ×⋯×(ak,d−δk,  bk,d+δk)\widetilde{B}_k \;=\; \bigl(a_{k,1} - \delta_k,\; b_{k,1} + \delta_k\bigr)\,\times \cdots \times \bigl(a_{k,d} - \delta_k,\; b_{k,d} + \delta_k\bigr)Bk​=(ak,1​−δk​,bk,1​+δk​)×⋯×(ak,d​−δk​,bk,d​+δk​)
still has volume close to vol(Bk)\mathrm{vol}(B_k)vol(Bk​). Specifically, the volume of B~k\widetilde{B}_kBk​ is
vol(B~k)  =  ∏i=1d((bk,i−ak,i)+2δk).\mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widetilde{B}_k\bigr) \;=\; \prod_{i=1}^d \bigl((b_{k,i} - a_{k,i}) + 2\delta_k\bigr).vol(Bk​)=i=1∏d​((bk,i​−ak,i​)+2δk​).
Since ∏i=1d(bk,i−ak,i)=vol(Bk)\prod_{i=1}^d (b_{k,i} - a_{k,i}) = \mathrm{vol}(B_k)∏i=1d​(bk,i​−ak,i​)=vol(Bk​), we can make δk\delta_kδk​ so small that
vol(B~k)  ≤  vol(Bk)  +  ε2k+1.\mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widetilde{B}_k\bigr) \;\le\; \mathrm{vol}(B_k) \;+\; \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{k+1}}.vol(Bk​)≤vol(Bk​)+2k+1ε​.
Such a choice is always possible because as δk→0\delta_k \to 0δk​→0, vol(B~k)\mathrm{vol}(\widetilde{B}_k)vol(Bk​) continuously decreases to vol(Bk)\mathrm{vol}(B_k)vol(Bk​).

  1. Controlling the total volume of the inflated boxes

By defining each δk\delta_kδk​ as above, we have for all kkk:
vol(B~k)  ≤  vol(Bk)+ε2k+1.\mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widetilde{B}_k\bigr) \;\le\; \mathrm{vol}(B_k) + \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{k+1}}.vol(Bk​)≤vol(Bk​)+2k+1ε​.
Hence
∑k=1∞vol(B~k)  ≤  ∑k=1∞(vol(Bk)+ε2k+1)  =  ∑k=1∞vol(Bk)  +  ∑k=1∞ε2k+1.\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widetilde{B}_k\bigr) \;\le\; \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \left(\mathrm{vol}(B_k) + \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{k+1}}\right) \;=\; \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(B_k) \;+\; \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{k+1}}.k=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)≤k=1∑∞​(vol(Bk​)+2k+1ε​)=k=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)+k=1∑∞​2k+1ε​.
Since
∑k=1∞vol(Bk)<μ∗(E)+ε2\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(B_k) < \mu^*(E) + \frac{\varepsilon}{2}∑k=1∞​vol(Bk​)<μ∗(E)+2ε​
by hypothesis, and
∑k=1∞ε2k+1=ε2\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2^{k+1}} = \tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}∑k=1∞​2k+1ε​=2ε​,
we obtain
∑k=1∞vol(B~k)  ≤  (μ∗(E)+ε2)  +  ε2  =  μ∗(E)+ε.\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widetilde{B}_k\bigr) \;\le\; \left(\mu^*(E) + \frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right) \;+\; \frac{\varepsilon}{2} \;=\; \mu^*(E) + \varepsilon.k=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)≤(μ∗(E)+2ε​)+2ε​=μ∗(E)+ε.

  1. Applying Heine–Borel to the open cover

Clearly,
E  ⊂  ⋃k=1∞Bk  ⊂  ⋃k=1∞B~k,E \;\subset\; \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} B_k \;\subset\; \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} \widetilde{B}_k,E⊂k=1⋃∞​Bk​⊂k=1⋃∞​Bk​,
and now {B~k}\{\widetilde{B}_k\}{Bk​} is an open cover of EEE. Because EEE is bounded (and we can also assume it is measurable or at least the part to be covered is within a bounded region), the Heine–Borel Theorem implies there is a finite subcover
E  ⊂  ⋃ℓ=1mB~kℓ  ⊂  ⋃k=1∞B~k.E \;\subset\; \bigcup_{\ell=1}^m \widetilde{B}_{k_\ell} \;\subset\; \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} \widetilde{B}_k.E⊂ℓ=1⋃m​Bkℓ​​⊂k=1⋃∞​Bk​.
Thus,
∑ℓ=1mvol(B~kℓ)  ≤  ∑k=1∞vol(B~k)  ≤  μ∗(E)  +  ε.\sum_{\ell=1}^m \mathrm{vol} \bigl(\widetilde{B}_{k_\ell}\bigr) \;\le\; \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widetilde{B}_k\bigr) \;\le\; \mu^*(E)\;+\;\varepsilon.ℓ=1∑m​vol(Bkℓ​​)≤k=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)≤μ∗(E)+ε.

Because {B~kℓ}ℓ=1m\bigl\{\widetilde{B}_{k_\ell}\bigr\}_{\ell=1}^m{Bkℓ​​}ℓ=1m​ is a finite cover of EEE by boxes (indeed, each B~kℓ\widetilde{B}_{k_\ell}Bkℓ​​ is still a box in the sense of having Cartesian product shape, just open intervals instead of closed), this finite subcover is admissible for the definition of the elementary (Jordan) measure μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E). Taking the infimum over all such finite covers yields
μ(E)  ≤  ∑ℓ=1mvol(B~kℓ)  ≤  μ∗(E)  +  ε.\mu(E) \;\le\; \sum_{\ell=1}^m \mathrm{vol}\bigl(\widetilde{B}_{k_\ell}\bigr) \;\le\; \mu^*(E)\;+\;\varepsilon.μ(E)≤ℓ=1∑m​vol(Bkℓ​​)≤μ∗(E)+ε.
Since ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0 was arbitrary, letting ε→0\varepsilon \to 0ε→0 shows
μ(E)  ≤  μ∗(E).\mu(E) \;\le\; \mu^*(E).μ(E)≤μ∗(E).

Summary of the inflation step

The key point is that by carefully choosing for each box BkB_kBk​ a small inflation parameter δk\delta_kδk​ so that the volume vol(B~k)\mathrm{vol}(\widetilde{B}_k)vol(Bk​) exceeds vol(Bk)\mathrm{vol}(B_k)vol(Bk​) by at most ε2k+1\frac{\varepsilon}{2^{k+1}}2k+1ε​, we ensure
∑k=1∞vol(B~k)  ≤  μ∗(E)+ε\sum_{k=1}^\infty \mathrm{vol}(\widetilde{B}_k) \;\le\; \mu^*(E) + \varepsilonk=1∑∞​vol(Bk​)≤μ∗(E)+ε
while still having an open cover of EEE. This allows us to apply Heine–Borel to extract a finite subcover of total volume at most μ∗(E)+ε\mu^*(E) + \varepsilonμ∗(E)+ε.

Disjoint boxes

Result 1

Thus far, we have considered elementary sets which are unions of pairwise disjoint boxes. Now, we introduce the notion of almost disjoint\textit{almost disjoint}almost disjoint boxes which are boxes whose interiors are disjoint which means that they share boundary.

For a set of almost disjoint boxes Bi,i=1,⋯ ,nB_i, i = 1, \cdots, nBi​,i=1,⋯,n, the elementary measure obeys the finite additivity property μ(B1∪B2∪⋯∪Bn)=∣B1∣+⋯+∣Bn∣\mu (B_1 \cup B_2 \cup \cdots \cup B_n) = |B_1| + \cdots + |B_n|μ(B1​∪B2​∪⋯∪Bn​)=∣B1​∣+⋯+∣Bn​∣.

With this setup, let EEE be a set such that it is a countable union of almost disjoint boxes. That is,
E=⋃i=1∞BiE = \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} B_iE=i=1⋃∞​Bi​
Then, we have to prove that:
μ∗(E)=∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\mu^*(E) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} |B_i|μ∗(E)=i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣

Below is a step‐by‐step argument showing why, if a set
E  =  ⋃i=1∞BiE \;=\; \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} B_iE=i=1⋃∞​Bi​
is written as a countable union of “almost disjoint” boxes BiB_iBi​ (i.e., boxes whose interiors are pairwise disjoint), then its Lebesgue outer measure is exactly the sum of the volumes of the BiB_iBi​:
μ∗(E)  =  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣.\mu^*(E) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} |B_i|.μ∗(E)=i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣.
Here, ∣Bi∣|B_i|∣Bi​∣ denotes the usual ddd‐dimensional volume of the box BiB_iBi​.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Two inequalities to prove
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We must show
μ∗(E)  ≤  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣andμ∗(E)  ≥  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣.\mu^*(E) \;\le\; \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} |B_i| \quad\text{and}\quad \mu^*(E) \;\ge\; \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} |B_i|.μ∗(E)≤i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣andμ∗(E)≥i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣.
Proving these two inequalities establishes
μ∗(E)=∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\mu^*(E)=\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|μ∗(E)=∑i=1∞​∣Bi​∣.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Showing
μ∗(E)  ≤  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\displaystyle \mu^*(E) \;\le\;\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|μ∗(E)≤i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Recall the definition of Lebesgue outer measure:
μ∗(E)  =  inf⁡{∑k=1∞vol(Ik)  ∣  E⊂⋃k=1∞Ik, each Ik a box}.\mu^*(E) \;=\; \inf\Bigl\{ \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{vol}(I_k) \;\Big|\; E \subset \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} I_k, \, \text{each } I_k \text{ a box} \Bigr\}.μ∗(E)=inf{k=1∑∞​vol(Ik​)​E⊂k=1⋃∞​Ik​,each Ik​ a box}.
Because
E=⋃i=1∞Bi\displaystyle E = \bigcup_{i=1}^\infty B_iE=i=1⋃∞​Bi​
is itself a countable cover of EEE by boxes,
∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣
is automatically one of the (infinitely many) sums inside the “infimum” defining μ∗(E)\mu^*(E)μ∗(E). Consequently,

μ∗(E)  ≤  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣.\mu^*(E) \;\le\; \sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|.μ∗(E)≤i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Showing
μ∗(E)  ≥  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\displaystyle \mu^*(E) \;\ge\;\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|μ∗(E)≥i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

This direction is more subtle. We use the fact that finite unions of almost disjoint boxes are elementary sets, and for those we already know (or can easily prove) that “Jordan measure” === “Lebesgue outer measure.” Concretely:

  1. For each nnn, define the finite union
    En  =  ⋃i=1n Bi.E_n \;=\; \bigcup_{i=1}^n \,B_i.En​=i=1⋃n​Bi​.
    Because B1,…,BnB_1,\dots,B_nB1​,…,Bn​ are almost disjoint (their interiors are pairwise disjoint), one can check (or recall) that the “elementary measure” μ(En)\mu(E_n)μ(En​) is exactly the sum of the volumes:
    μ(En)  =  ∑i=1n∣Bi∣.\mu(E_n) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^n |B_i|.μ(En​)=i=1∑n​∣Bi​∣.
    Moreover, “elementary measure” μ(En)\mu(E_n)μ(En​) coincides with the Jordan outer measure μ∗,(J)(En)\mu^{*,(J)}(E_n)μ∗,(J)(En​), and for these nice finite unions of boxes, we also know
    μ∗,(J)(En)=μ∗(En)\mu^{*,(J)}(E_n) = \mu^*(E_n)μ∗,(J)(En​)=μ∗(En​).
    Hence
    μ∗(En)  =  μ(En)  =  ∑i=1n∣Bi∣.\mu^*(E_n) \;=\; \mu(E_n) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^n |B_i|.μ∗(En​)=μ(En​)=i=1∑n​∣Bi​∣.

  2. Observe that each EnE_nEn​ is contained in EEE. By the monotonicity of outer measure,
    En  ⊂  E  ⟹  μ∗(En)  ≤  μ∗(E).E_n \;\subset\; E \;\Longrightarrow\; \mu^*(E_n)\;\le\;\mu^*(E).En​⊂E⟹μ∗(En​)≤μ∗(E).
    Therefore
    ∑i=1n∣Bi∣  =  μ∗(En)  ≤  μ∗(E).\sum_{i=1}^n |B_i| \;=\; \mu^*(E_n) \;\le\; \mu^*(E).i=1∑n​∣Bi​∣=μ∗(En​)≤μ∗(E).

  3. Since the above holds for every finite nnn, we let n→∞n\to\inftyn→∞. The partial sums ∑i=1n∣Bi∣\sum_{i=1}^n |B_i|∑i=1n​∣Bi​∣ increase to ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|∑i=1∞​∣Bi​∣. Hence
    ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣    =    lim⁡n→∞ ∑i=1n∣Bi∣    ≤    μ∗(E).\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i| \;\;=\;\; \lim_{n\to\infty} \,\sum_{i=1}^n |B_i| \;\;\le\;\; \mu^*(E).i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣=n→∞lim​i=1∑n​∣Bi​∣≤μ∗(E).
    Thus we obtain
    μ∗(E)  ≥  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣.\mu^*(E) \;\ge\;\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|.μ∗(E)≥i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Combining both inequalities,

• From the covering definition:
μ∗(E)  ≤  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\displaystyle \mu^*(E)\;\le\;\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|μ∗(E)≤i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣.
• From the monotonicity and finite‐union argument:
μ∗(E)  ≥  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\displaystyle \mu^*(E)\;\ge\;\sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|μ∗(E)≥i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣.

we conclude
μ∗(E)  =  ∑i=1∞∣Bi∣.\mu^*(E) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^\infty |B_i|.μ∗(E)=i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣.

Hence, whenever EEE is (by definition) a countable union of almost disjoint boxes {Bi}\{B_i\}{Bi​}, its Lebesgue outer measure is exactly the sum of the volumes of those boxes.

Result 2

For E⊂RdE \subset R^dE⊂Rd and bounded, let EEE be the countable union of almost disjoint boxes. In this case, we have
μ∗(E)=μ∗,(J)(E)\mu^*(E) = \mu_{*,(J)} (E)μ∗(E)=μ∗,(J)​(E)
the Lebesgue outer measure is equal to the inner Jordan measure. We need to prove this.

Here are some initial thoughts on the proof.

Let Bi,i=1,⋯ ,∞B_i, i = 1, \cdots, \inftyBi​,i=1,⋯,∞ be the almost disjoint boxes. We can show that
μ∗(E)=∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\mu*(E) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} | B_i |μ∗(E)=i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣
where ∣Bi∣=ℓ(Bi)|B_i| = \ell(B_i)∣Bi​∣=ℓ(Bi​) is the usual ddd-dimensional volume of the box. So, it seems that we have
to prove two inequalities:
μ∗,(J)(E)≤∑i=1∞∣Bi∣μ∗,(J)(E)≥∑i=1∞∣Bi∣\mu_{*,(J)}(E) \leq \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} | B_i | \qquad \mu_{*,(J)}(E) \geq \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} |B_i|μ∗,(J)​(E)≤i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣μ∗,(J)​(E)≥i=1∑∞​∣Bi​∣

the first inequality rough sketch: we can choose a finite subset of the given BiB_iBi​. Let NNN be the number of the boxes. We have to choose NNN and we have to take a supremum meaning we have to choose which NNN of the countable boxes BiB_iBi​ we choose.

Foramlize or modify this argument.

Below is a succinct version of the proof with a simplified indexing in Step 2, removing any extraneous notation.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Setting and Definitions
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let E⊂RdE \subset \mathbb{R}^dE⊂Rd be bounded, and suppose
E  =  ⋃i=1∞Bi,E \;=\; \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} B_i,E=i=1⋃∞​Bi​,
where each BiB_iBi​ is a (Jordan-measurable) box and the BiB_iBi​ are “almost disjoint” (their interiors are disjoint, and overlaps can only occur on boundaries of measure zero). Let ℓ(Bi)\ell(B_i)ℓ(Bi​) denote the usual ddd-dimensional volume of BiB_iBi​.

We wish to show
μ∗(E)  =  μ∗,(J)(E),\mu^*(E) \;=\; \mu_{*,(J)}(E),μ∗(E)=μ∗,(J)​(E),
where μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is the Lebesgue outer measure, and
μ∗,(J)(E)  =  sup⁡{∑k=1mℓ(Jk)  ∣  J1,…,Jm⊂E,    (Jk pairwise disjoint boxes)}\mu_{*,(J)}(E) \;=\; \sup \Bigl\{ \sum_{k=1}^{m} \ell(J_k) \;\Bigm|\; J_1,\dots,J_m \subset E,\;\; (J_k \text{ pairwise disjoint boxes}) \Bigr\}μ∗,(J)​(E)=sup{k=1∑m​ℓ(Jk​)​J1​,…,Jm​⊂E,(Jk​ pairwise disjoint boxes)}
is the inner Jordan measure. In particular, a key step is to prove
μ∗,(J)(E)    ≤    ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi).\mu_{*,(J)}(E) \;\;\le\;\; \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \ell(B_i).μ∗,(J)​(E)≤i=1∑∞​ℓ(Bi​).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) The Inequality μ∗,(J)(E)  ≤  ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi)\mu_{*,(J)}(E) \;\le\; \sum_{i=1}^\infty \ell(B_i)μ∗,(J)​(E)≤∑i=1∞​ℓ(Bi​)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By definition,
μ∗,(J)(E)  =  sup⁡{∑k=1mℓ(Jk)  ∣  Jk⊂E,  (Jk disjoint),  m∈N}.\mu_{*,(J)}(E) \;=\; \sup \Bigl\{ \sum_{k=1}^{m} \ell(J_k) \;\Bigm|\; J_k\subset E,\; (J_k \text{ disjoint}), \; m\in\mathbb{N} \Bigr\}.μ∗,(J)​(E)=sup{k=1∑m​ℓ(Jk​)​Jk​⊂E,(Jk​ disjoint),m∈N}.
Any finite family {J1,…,Jm}\{J_1,\dots,J_m\}{J1​,…,Jm​} of disjoint boxes is contained in EEE. In particular, we can also consider finite subcollections taken directly from our given family {Bi}\{B_i\}{Bi​}. Concretely,

• Pick any finite subcollection of the BiB_iBi​; for simplicity, label them
B1,  B2,  …,  BNB_1,\; B_2,\;\dots,\; B_NB1​,B2​,…,BN​
(which is just a finite subset of {Bi}i=1∞\{B_i\}_{i=1}^\infty{Bi​}i=1∞​).
• Because the BiB_iBi​ are almost disjoint, we have
∑k=1Nℓ(Bk)    ≤    ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi).\sum_{k=1}^N \ell\bigl(B_k\bigr) \;\;\le\;\; \sum_{i=1}^\infty \ell\bigl(B_i\bigr).k=1∑N​ℓ(Bk​)≤i=1∑∞​ℓ(Bi​).
• By definition of μ∗,(J)(E)\mu_{*,(J)}(E)μ∗,(J)​(E), we take the supremum of such finite-sum volumes of disjoint boxes \emph{inside} EEE. But every finite subcollection from the BiB_iBi​ is one of those valid families. Thus each finite sum is at most ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi)\sum_{i=1}^\infty \ell(B_i)∑i=1∞​ℓ(Bi​), and taking the supremum cannot exceed this same infinite sum.

Hence
μ∗,(J)(E)    ≤    ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi),\mu_{*,(J)}(E) \;\;\le\;\; \sum_{i=1}^\infty \ell(B_i),μ∗,(J)​(E)≤i=1∑∞​ℓ(Bi​),
as desired.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Remarks on the Reverse Inequality and Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• One similarly shows
μ∗(E)  =  ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi).\mu^*(E) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^{\infty}\ell(B_i).μ∗(E)=i=1∑∞​ℓ(Bi​).
(Here we use that EEE is covered by the BiB_iBi​, apply subadditivity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗, and argue each BiB_iBi​ is Jordan measurable. By approximating each BiB_iBi​ from the inside, we obtain that ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi)\sum_{i=1}^\infty \ell(B_i)∑i=1∞​ℓ(Bi​) can be matched arbitrarily closely by finite disjoint unions inside EEE.)

• Combining these, one arrives at
μ∗(E)  =  ∑i=1∞ℓ(Bi)  =  μ∗,(J)(E),\mu^*(E) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^{\infty}\ell(B_i) \;=\; \mu_{*,(J)}(E),μ∗(E)=i=1∑∞​ℓ(Bi​)=μ∗,(J)​(E),
completing the proof that the Lebesgue outer measure of EEE equals its inner Jordan measure (under the assumption that EEE is covered by countably many almost disjoint Jordan-measurable boxes).

Closed Dyadic cubes in RdR^dRd

What is the concept of a closed dyadic cube in RdR^dRd? In particular a cube of side length 2−n2^{-n}2−n for some non-negative integer nnn.

A closed dyadic cube in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd is a closed cube whose side length is a negative power of 2, and whose corners lie in the scaled integer lattice. Concretely, for a nonnegative integer n∈{0,1,2,… }n\in \{0,1,2,\dots\}n∈{0,1,2,…} and an integer vector
k  =  (k1,k2,…,kd)∈Zd,k \;=\; (k_1,k_2,\dots,k_d)\in \mathbb{Z}^d,k=(k1​,k2​,…,kd​)∈Zd,
the corresponding closed dyadic cube of side length 2−n2^{-n}2−n is given by
Qn,k  =  ∏j=1d[kj2n,kj+12n].Q_{n,k} \;=\; \prod_{j=1}^d \biggl[ \tfrac{k_j}{2^n}, \tfrac{k_j + 1}{2^n} \biggr].Qn,k​=j=1∏d​[2nkj​​,2nkj​+1​].
Hence:

  1. Each coordinate direction has length 2−n2^{-n}2−n.
  2. Each coordinate interval is of the form [kj2n, kj+12n]\bigl[\tfrac{k_j}{2^n},\,\tfrac{k_j+1}{2^n}\bigr][2nkj​​,2nkj​+1​].
  3. “Closed” means each interval includes its endpoints, making the product a closed subset of Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

Such cubes play a significant role in analysis and measure theory (for example, in constructing partitions of Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd and in certain proofs related to Lebesgue integration).

It appears that this cube Qn,kQ_{n,k}Qn,k​ has the following properties:

  1. It covers RdR^dRd
  2. a mesh of such cubes are almost disjoint.

Formalize this

Below is a concise statement and proof of the two key facts about closed dyadic cubes in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1. Definition of a Closed Dyadic Cube
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A (closed) dyadic cube of side length 2−n2^{-n}2−n (for n∈{0,1,2,… }n \in \{0,1,2,\dots\}n∈{0,1,2,…}) is of the form
Qn,k  =  ∏j=1d[kj2n,kj+12n],Q_{n,k} \;=\; \prod_{j=1}^d \biggl[ \tfrac{k_j}{2^n}, \tfrac{k_j + 1}{2^n} \biggr],Qn,k​=j=1∏d​[2nkj​​,2nkj​+1​],
where k=(k1,…,kd)k = (k_1,\dots,k_d)k=(k1​,…,kd​) is in Zd\mathbb{Z}^dZd.
Thus, each edge has length 2−n2^{-n}2−n, and the coordinates of the corners are integer multiples of 2−n2^{-n}2−n.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Covering Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd with Dyadic Cubes
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For each fixed nnn, consider all dyadic cubes {Qn,k}k∈Zd\{Q_{n,k}\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^d}{Qn,k​}k∈Zd​. We claim
Rd  =  ⋃k∈ZdQn,k.\mathbb{R}^d \;=\; \bigcup_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^d} Q_{n,k}.Rd=k∈Zd⋃​Qn,k​.

• Proof:
Let x∈Rdx \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd with coordinates x=(x1,…,xd)x = (x_1,\dots,x_d)x=(x1​,…,xd​). For each coordinate xjx_jxj​, define kj=⌊2nxj⌋k_j = \lfloor 2^n x_j \rfloorkj​=⌊2nxj​⌋, the greatest integer ≤2nxj\le 2^n x_j≤2nxj​. Then
kj2n  ≤  xj  <  kj+12n.\frac{k_j}{2^n} \;\le\; x_j \;<\; \frac{k_j + 1}{2^n}.2nkj​​≤xj​<2nkj​+1​.
Hence xj∈[kj2n, kj+12n]x_j \in \bigl[\tfrac{k_j}{2^n},\,\tfrac{k_j+1}{2^n}\bigr]xj​∈[2nkj​​,2nkj​+1​] for each jjj. Consequently, x∈Qn,kx \in Q_{n,k}x∈Qn,k​ for k=(k1,…,kd)k = (k_1,\dots,k_d)k=(k1​,…,kd​). Since xxx was arbitrary, this shows
⋃k∈ZdQn,k=Rd.\bigcup_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^d} Q_{n,k} = \mathbb{R}^d.⋃k∈Zd​Qn,k​=Rd.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Almost Disjointness
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The cubes Qn,kQ_{n,k}Qn,k​ and Qn,k′Q_{n,k'}Qn,k′​ (for a fixed nnn) may intersect along boundaries, but they do not overlap in their interiors. More precisely:

• If k≠k′k \neq k'k=k′, then
int(Qn,k)  ∩  int(Qn,k′)  =  ∅.\mathrm{int}(Q_{n,k}) \;\cap\; \mathrm{int}(Q_{n,k'}) \;=\; \varnothing.int(Qn,k​)∩int(Qn,k′​)=∅.
Indeed, for the interiors to intersect, we would need each coordinate interval
(kj2n,kj+12n)\bigl(\tfrac{k_j}{2^n},\tfrac{k_j+1}{2^n}\bigr)(2nkj​​,2nkj​+1​)
to coincide with
(kj′2n,kj′+12n)\bigl(\tfrac{k'_j}{2^n},\tfrac{k'_j+1}{2^n}\bigr)(2nkj′​​,2nkj′​+1​)
in an open sub-interval. That would require kj=kj′k_j = k'_jkj​=kj′​ for all jjj. Hence if k≠k′k \neq k'k=k′, the interiors are disjoint. They can only meet on a boundary set, which is a ℓd\ell^dℓd-measure-zero subset of Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

Hence, for each nnn, the family {Qn,k}k∈Zd\{Q_{n,k}\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^d}{Qn,k​}k∈Zd​ forms a “tiling” (or partition) of Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd up to boundaries of measure zero. In other words:

  1. The union of all such Qn,kQ_{n,k}Qn,k​ equals Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.
  2. Their interiors are pairwise disjoint.
  3. Consequently, any overlap can only happen along lower-dimensional faces (boundaries).

This is precisely what is often meant by saying these dyadic cubes form an “almost disjoint” covering of Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.
